[![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/casinos-gaming/) ​Look no further than one of the Pittsburgh area's full-service casinos for entertainment and fun day and night! [Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/casinos-gaming/) [![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/memorials/) [Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/memorials/) Credit \| JP Diroll # Fishing, Kayaking & Boating Pittsburgh sits at a unique confluence of rivers unlike any other in the world, diverse and more abundant than any other state except Alaska. Pittsburgh sits at a unique confluence of rivers unlike any other in the world, diverse and more abundant than any other state except Alaska. The three rivers that meet in Pittsburgh are actually a vast watershed of more than a dozen unique creeks and river systems that include more than 30,000 miles of rivers and streams extending into New York and West Virginia. These clean and accessible waters have become a stunning icon of Pittsburgh's environmental transformation. ## Kayaking, Paddling & Rowing Pittsburgh's rivers are ideal for sculling, kayaking and canoeing. The [Three Rivers Water Trail System](http://www.friendsoftheriverfront.org/ "Three Rivers Water Trail System") is a project intended to develop the rivers as recreational waterways with convenient access points and day-use sites; the Allegheny River Trail is already complete. On the Allegheny River in the heart of [Downtown Pittsburgh](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/neighborhoods/downtown-pittsburgh/), [Kayak Pittsburgh](https://ventureoutdoors.org/kayak-pittsburgh/ "Kayak Pittsburgh") rents solo and tandem kayaks, canoes, and hydrobikes for peaceful urban exploration. Located under the 31st Street Bridge on the [North Shore](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/neighborhoods/north-shore-north-side/), the [Three Rivers Rowing Association](http://www.threeriversrowing.org/ "Three Rivers Rowing Association") offers rowing, kayaking, and dragon boating to individuals, schools and organizations of all skill levels. The [Steel City Rowing Club](http://www.steelcityrowing.org/ "Steel City Rowing Club") is the only rowing organization on the upper Allegheny River, which boasts nine full miles of rowing without locks or dams, on relatively undeveloped wetlands. ## Boating Pittsburgh has the second-largest number of registered pleasure boats in the country. There are [seventeen marinas](http://www.fish.state.pa.us/marinas.htm "Seventeen Marinas") in Allegheny County along the three rivers, offering river access, dining and boat maintenance. [Station Square](http://www.stationsquare.com/ "Station Square") in the [South Side](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/neighborhoods/south-side/) offers public docks at Bessemer Court, for easy river access to downtown shopping and dining. Also within the city limits are four [public boat launches](http://www.lrp.usace.army.mil/Portals/72/docs/Recreation/BOAT%20LAUNCHING%20RAMPS.pdf "Public Boat Launches"), one on the Monongahela River in the South Side and three along the Allegheny River Trail. Visitors can rent kayaks and boats at the North Park Boathouse through [Venture Outdoors](http://www.ventureoutdoors.org/). ## Fishing There are 38.3 miles of river shoreline within the city limits. [Venture Outdoors](http://www.ventureoutdoors.org/ "Venture Outdoors") organizes weekly lunchtime fishing in [Point State Park](http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/point/ "link to Point State Park website") or [North Shore Riverfront Park](http://www.pgh-sea.com/northshoreriverfrontpark.htm "North Shore Riverfront Park"), with an instructor on hand to help the novice and expert alike. Regionally, western Pennsylvania's [state parks](http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/ "State Parks") abound with well-stocked lakes and streams. Deer Lakes Park and North Park both have [accessible fishing piers](https://www.alleghenycounty.us/Parks-and-Events/Activities/Fishing). ## Whitewater In [Ohiopyle State Park](http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/ "Ohiopyle State Park"), the Youghiogheny River boasts class III and IV rapids and is considered to be some of the best whitewater in the east. [White Water Adventurers](http://www.wwaraft.com/ "White Water Adventurers") and [Laurel Highlands River Tours](http://www.laurelhighlands.com/ "Laurel Highlands River Tours") organize rafting and kayaking for groups of all sizes and skill levels on the

Between 2006 and 2011, the [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_metropolitan_area "Pittsburgh metropolitan area") [metropolitan statistical area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_statistical_area "Metropolitan statistical area") (MSA) experienced over 10% appreciation in housing prices, the highest appreciation of the largest 25 metropolitan statistical areas in the United States, with 22 of the largest 25 metropolitan statistical areas experiencing depreciations in housing values.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-50) In September 2009, the [2009 G20 Pittsburgh summit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_G20_Pittsburgh_summit "2009 G20 Pittsburgh summit") was held in Pittsburgh.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-51) ## Geography \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Geography")\] See also: [Pittsburgh metropolitan area § Regional identity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_metropolitan_area#Regional_identity "Pittsburgh metropolitan area") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Duquesne_Incline%2C_Pittsburgh_PA_%288899995839%29.jpg/250px-Duquesne_Incline%2C_Pittsburgh_PA_%288899995839%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Duquesne_Incline,_Pittsburgh_PA_(8899995839).jpg) The [Duquesne Incline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duquesne_Incline "Duquesne Incline") from [Mount Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Washington,_Pittsburgh_(mountain) "Mount Washington, Pittsburgh (mountain)") Pittsburgh has an area of 58.3 square miles (151 km2), of which 55.6 square miles (144 km2) is land and 2.8 square miles (7.3 km2), or 4.75%, is water. The [80th meridian west](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/80th_meridian_west "80th meridian west") passes directly through the city's downtown. The city is located on the [Allegheny Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_Plateau "Allegheny Plateau"), within the [ecoregion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion") of the [Western Allegheny Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Allegheny_Plateau_(ecoregion) "Western Allegheny Plateau (ecoregion)").[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-52) The [Downtown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Pittsburgh "Downtown Pittsburgh") area (also known as the Golden Triangle) sits where the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") flows from the northeast and the [Monongahela River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monongahela_River "Monongahela River") from the southeast to form the [Ohio River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River"). The convergence is at [Point State Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_State_Park "Point State Park") and is referred to as "the Point." The city extends east to include the [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)") and [Shadyside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadyside_(Pittsburgh) "Shadyside (Pittsburgh)") sections, which are home to the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), [Carnegie Mellon University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University "Carnegie Mellon University"), [Chatham University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatham_University "Chatham University"), [Carnegie Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh") and [Library](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh"), and many other educational, medical, and cultural institutions. The southern, western, and northern areas of the city are primarily residential. Many [Pittsburgh neighborhoods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_neighborhoods "List of Pittsburgh neighborhoods") are steeply sloped with two-lane roads. More than a quarter of neighborhood names make reference to "hills," "heights," or similar features.[\[a\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-53) The [steps of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steps_of_Pittsburgh "Steps of Pittsburgh") consist of 800 sets of outdoor public stairways with 44,645 treads and 24,090 vertical feet. They include hundreds of streets composed entirely of stairs, and many other steep streets with stairs for sidewalks.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-54) Many provide vistas of the Pittsburgh area while attracting hikers and fitness walkers.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-55) Bike and walking trails have been built to border many of the city's rivers and hollows. The [Great Allegheny Passage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Allegheny_Passage "Great Allegheny Passage") and [Chesapeake and Ohio Canal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chesapeake_and_Ohio_Canal "Chesapeake and Ohio Canal") Towpath connect the city directly to downtown Washington, D.C. (some 335 miles \[539 km\] away) with a continuous bike/running trail. ### Cityscape \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Cityscape")\] Main articles: [Downtown Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Pittsburgh "Downtown Pittsburgh"), [North Side (Pittsburgh)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_(Pittsburgh) "North Side (Pittsburgh)"), [South Side (Pittsburgh)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Side_(Pittsburgh) "South Side (Pittsburgh)"), and [West End (Pittsburgh)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_End_(Pittsburgh) "West End (Pittsburgh)") See also: [List of Pittsburgh neighborhoods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_neighborhoods "List of Pittsburgh neighborhoods"), [List of tallest buildings in Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Pittsburgh "List of tallest buildings in Pittsburgh"), [List of City of Pittsburgh historic designations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_City_of_Pittsburgh_historic_designations "List of City of Pittsburgh historic designations"), and [List of Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation Historic Landmarks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_History_and_Landmarks_Foundation_Historic_Landmarks "List of Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation Historic Landmarks") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Pittsburgh_Pennsylvania_neighborhoods_fade.svg/250px-Pittsburgh_Pennsylvania_neighborhoods_fade.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Pennsylvania_neighborhoods_fade.svg) Pittsburgh's [90 distinct neighborhoods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_neighborhoods "List

question: After the British victory in the 1750s, which nation ceded territories east of the Mississippi?
answer: After the British victory in the 1750s, France ceded their territories east of the Mississippi River.

contexts.text: men built a wagon road 12 feet (3.7 m) wide, that when complete, was the first road to cross the [Appalachian Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains"). [Braddock's Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braddock_Road_(Braddock_expedition) "Braddock Road (Braddock expedition)"), as it was known, blazed the way for the future [National Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Road "National Road") (US40). The expedition crossed the [Monongahela River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monongahela_River "Monongahela River") on July 9, 1755. French troops from Fort Duquesne ambushed Braddock's expedition at [Braddock's Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braddock%27s_Field "Braddock's Field"), nine miles (14 km) from Fort Duquesne.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-jubilee-20) In the [Battle of the Monongahela](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braddock_expedition#Battle_of_the_Monongahela "Braddock expedition"), the French inflicted heavy losses on the British, and Braddock was mortally wounded.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) The surviving British and colonial forces retreated. This left the French and their Native American allies with dominion over the upper Ohio valley.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-ftpitt-15) On September 8, 1756, an [expedition of 300 militiamen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kittanning_Expedition "Kittanning Expedition") destroyed the Shawnee and Lenape village of [Kittanning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kittanning_(village) "Kittanning (village)"), and in the summer of 1758, [British Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Army "British Army") officer [John Forbes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Forbes_(General) "John Forbes (General)") began a campaign to capture Fort Duquesne.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) At the head of 7,000 regular and colonial troops, Forbes built [Fort Ligonier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Ligonier "Fort Ligonier") and [Fort Bedford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Bedford "Fort Bedford"), from where he cut a wagon road over the Allegheny Mountains, later known as Forbes' Road. On the night of September 13–14, 1758, an advance column under [Major James Grant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Grant_(British_Army_officer,_born_1720) "James Grant (British Army officer, born 1720)") was annihilated in the [Battle of Fort Duquesne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Duquesne "Battle of Fort Duquesne").[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) The battleground, the high hill east of the Point, was named Grant's Hill in his memory. With this defeat, Forbes decided to wait until spring. But when he heard that the French had lost [Fort Frontenac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Frontenac "Fort Frontenac") and largely evacuated [Fort Duquesne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Duquesne "Fort Duquesne"), he planned an immediate attack. Hopelessly outnumbered, the French abandoned and razed Fort Duquesne. Forbes occupied the burned fort on November 25, 1758, and ordered the construction of [Fort Pitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_(Pennsylvania) "Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)"), named after British Secretary of State [William Pitt the Elder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Pitt_the_Elder "William Pitt the Elder"). He also named the settlement between the rivers, "Pittsborough" (see [Etymology of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etymology_of_Pittsburgh "Etymology of Pittsburgh")).[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Lorant-11)[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-ftpitt-15) The British garrison at Fort Pitt made substantial improvements to its fortification.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Lorant-11) The French never attacked Fort Pitt and the war soon ended with the [Treaty of Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1763) "Treaty of Paris (1763)") and French defeat.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-ftpitt-15) They ceded their territories east of the Mississippi River. ## Gateway to the West (1763–1799) \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Gateway to the West (1763–1799)")\] In 1760, the first considerable European settlement around Fort Pitt began to grow. Traders and settlers built two groups of houses and cabins, the "lower town", near the fort's ramparts, and the "upper town", along the Monongahela as far as present-day Market Street. In April 1761, a census ordered by Colonel [Henry Bouquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Bouquet "Henry Bouquet") and conducted by [William Clapham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Clapham "William Clapham") counted 332 people and 104 houses.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21)[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-22): 148 After Britain's victory in the French and Indian War, increasing dissatisfaction among Native Americans with the continuing encroachment of settlers on lands that had been agreed would be Indian-occupied (both in the 1758 Treaty of Easton and in the Royal Proclamation of

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#bodyContent) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg/70px-Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg.png)\\ Photograph a historic site, help Wikipedia, and win a prize. Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Thaddeus_M._Fowler_-_Pittsburgh%2C_Pennsylvania_1902.jpg/500px-Thaddeus_M._Fowler_-_Pittsburgh%2C_Pennsylvania_1902.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Thaddeus_M._Fowler_-_Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania_1902.jpg) Pittsburgh in 1902. Lithograph by [Thaddeus Mortimer Fowler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thaddeus_Mortimer_Fowler "Thaddeus Mortimer Fowler"). The **history of Pittsburgh** began with centuries of Native American civilization in the modern [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh") region, known as _Jaödeogë’_ in the [Seneca language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seneca_language "Seneca language").[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Chafe2013-1) Eventually, European explorers encountered the strategic confluence where the [Allegheny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") and [Monongahela Rivers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monongahela_River "Monongahela River") meet to form the [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River"), which leads to the Mississippi River. The area became a battleground when [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_France "Kingdom of France") and [Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") [fought for control in the 1750s](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War"). When the British were victorious, the French ceded control of territories east of the Mississippi. Following [American independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War") in 1783, the village around [Fort Pitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_(Pennsylvania) "Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)") continued to grow. The region saw the short-lived [Whiskey Rebellion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whiskey_Rebellion "Whiskey Rebellion"), when farmers rebelled against federal taxes on whiskey. The [War of 1812](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812") cut off the supply of British goods, stimulating American manufacture. By 1815, Pittsburgh was producing large quantities of iron, brass, tin, and glass products. By the 1840s, Pittsburgh had grown to be one of the largest cities west of the [Allegheny Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_Mountains "Allegheny Mountains"). Production of steel began in 1875. During the 1877 [railway riots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Railway_Riots "Pittsburgh Railway Riots") it was the site of the most violence and damage in any city affected by the [nationwide strikes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Railroad_Strike_of_1877 "Great Railroad Strike of 1877") of that summer. Workers protested against cuts in wages, burning down buildings at the railyards, including 100 train engines and more than 1,000 cars. Forty men were killed, most of them strikers. By 1911, Pittsburgh was producing half the nation's steel. Pittsburgh was a Republican party stronghold until 1932. The soaring unemployment of the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in the United States"), the New Deal relief programs and the rise of powerful labor unions in the 1930s turned the city into a liberal stronghold of the [New Deal Coalition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Deal_Coalition "New Deal Coalition") under powerful Democratic mayors. In World War II, it was the center of the " [Arsenal of Democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arsenal_of_Democracy "Arsenal of Democracy")", producing munitions for the Allied war effort as prosperity returned. Following World War II, Pittsburgh launched a clean air and civic revitalization project known as the "Renaissance". The industrial base continued to expand through the 1960s, but after 1970 foreign competition led to the collapse of the steel industry, with massive layoffs and mill closures. Top corporate headquarters moved out in the 1980s. In 2007 the city lost its status as a major transportation hub. The population of the [Pittsburgh metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_metropolitan_area "Pittsburgh metropolitan area") is holding steady at 2.4 million; 65% of its residents are of European descent and 35% are minorities. ## Native American era \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Native American era")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/NativeTowns_Pittsburgh.png/500px-NativeTowns_Pittsburgh.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:NativeTowns_Pittsburgh.png) Native Americans lived near the forks of the Ohio for thousands of years. These are some important villages, most c. 1750s,

Mississippi River. ## Gateway to the West (1763–1799) \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Gateway to the West (1763–1799)")\] In 1760, the first considerable European settlement around Fort Pitt began to grow. Traders and settlers built two groups of houses and cabins, the "lower town", near the fort's ramparts, and the "upper town", along the Monongahela as far as present-day Market Street. In April 1761, a census ordered by Colonel [Henry Bouquet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Bouquet "Henry Bouquet") and conducted by [William Clapham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Clapham "William Clapham") counted 332 people and 104 houses.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21)[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-22): 148 After Britain's victory in the French and Indian War, increasing dissatisfaction among Native Americans with the continuing encroachment of settlers on lands that had been agreed would be Indian-occupied (both in the 1758 Treaty of Easton and in the Royal Proclamation of 1763 the British authorities had decreed that there would be no British-American settlements west of the Alleghenies, but the authorities had been unable or unwilling to enforce these decrees) led to the outbreak of [Pontiac's War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontiac%27s_War "Pontiac's War"). The [Odawa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odawa "Odawa") leader [Pontiac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontiac_(Ottawa_leader) "Pontiac (Ottawa leader)") launched an offensive against British forts in May 1763. Native American tribes from the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes overran numerous British forts; one of their most important targets was Fort Pitt. Receiving warning of the coming attack, Captain Simeon Ecuyer, the Swiss officer in command of the garrison, prepared for a siege. He leveled the houses outside the ramparts and ordered all settlers into the fort: 330 men, 104 women, and 196 children sought refuge inside its ramparts.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Lorant-11) Captain Ecuyer also gathered stores, which included hundreds of barrels of pork and beef. Pontiac's forces attacked the fort on June 22, 1763, and the [siege of Fort Pitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Fort_Pitt "Siege of Fort Pitt") lasted for two months.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-ftpitt-15) Pontiac's warriors kept up a continuous, though ineffective, fire on it from July 27 through August 1, 1763.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) They drew off to confront the relieving party under Colonel Bouquet, which defeated them in the [Battle of Bushy Run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Bushy_Run "Battle of Bushy Run").[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) This victory ensured British dominion over the forks of the Ohio, if not the entire Ohio valley. In 1764 Colonel Bouquet added a [redoubt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redoubt "Redoubt"), the [Fort Pitt Blockhouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_Blockhouse "Fort Pitt Blockhouse"), which still stands, the sole remaining structure from Fort Pitt and the oldest authenticated building west of the [Allegheny Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_Mountains "Allegheny Mountains").[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-ftpitt-15) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Fort_Pitt_1795_large.jpg/330px-Fort_Pitt_1795_large.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fort_Pitt_1795_large.jpg) Fort Pitt, 1795 The [Iroquois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois") signed the [Fort Stanwix Treaty of 1768](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Stanwix_Treaty_of_1768 "Fort Stanwix Treaty of 1768"), ceding the lands south of the Ohio to the [British Crown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Crown "The Crown").[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-EB1911-21) European expansion into the upper Ohio valley increased. An estimated 4,000 to 5,000 families settled in western Pennsylvania between 1768 and 1770. Of these settlers, about a third were [English-American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_Americans "English Americans"), another third were [Scotch-Irish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotch-Irish_Americans "Scotch-Irish Americans"), and the rest were [Welsh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_Americans "Welsh Americans"), [German](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Americans "German Americans") and others.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Bartlett-23) These groups tended to settle together in small farming communities, but often their households were not within hailing distance. The life of a settler family was one of relentless hard work: clearing the forest, stumping the fields, building cabins and barns, planting, weeding,

question: What is the nickname of Pittsburgh’s former Civic Arena?
answer: The nickname of Pittsburgh’s former Civic Arena was "the Igloo."

contexts.text: 1936 to 1967 (with a short break from 1956 to 1961). In the spring of 1965, [Jack McGregor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_McGregor "Jack McGregor"), a [state senator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_senator "State senator") from [Kittanning, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kittanning,_Pennsylvania "Kittanning, Pennsylvania"), began lobbying campaign contributors and community leaders to bring an NHL franchise back to Pittsburgh. The group focused on leveraging the NHL as an [urban renewal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_renewal "Urban renewal") tool for Pittsburgh. The senator formed a group of local investors that included [H. J. Heinz Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._J._Heinz_Company "H. J. Heinz Company") heir [H. J. Heinz III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._John_Heinz_III "H. John Heinz III"), [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")' owner [Art Rooney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Rooney "Art Rooney") and the [Mellon family](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_family "Mellon family")'s [Richard Mellon Scaife](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Mellon_Scaife "Richard Mellon Scaife"). The [projected league expansion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1967_NHL_expansion "1967 NHL expansion") depended on securing votes from the [then-current NHL owners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_Six "Original Six"); to ensure Pittsburgh would be selected as one of the expansion cities, McGregor enlisted Rooney to petition votes from [James D. Norris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_D._Norris "James D. Norris"), owner of the [Chicago Black Hawks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Blackhawks "Chicago Blackhawks") and his brother [Bruce Norris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Norris_(ice_hockey) "Bruce Norris (ice hockey)"), owner of the [Detroit Red Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings"). The effort was successful, and on February 8, 1966, the [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") awarded an [expansion team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expansion_team "Expansion team") to Pittsburgh for the [1967–68 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1967%E2%80%9368_NHL_season "1967–68 NHL season"). The Penguins paid $2.5 million ($24.5 million today) for their entry and $750,000 ($7.1 million today) more for start-up costs. The [Civic Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_Arena_(Pittsburgh) "Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)")'s capacity was boosted from 10,732 to 12,500 to meet the NHL requirements for expansion. The Penguins also paid an indemnification bill to settle with the Detroit Red Wings, which owned the Pittsburgh Hornets franchise. The investor group named McGregor president and chief executive officer, and he represented Pittsburgh on the NHL's Board of Governors.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-Steel_City_Legend-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-History2016-6) [![Photograph of the Civic Arena](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Pittsburgh-pennsylvania-mellon-arena-2007.jpg/250px-Pittsburgh-pennsylvania-mellon-arena-2007.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh-pennsylvania-mellon-arena-2007.jpg) The [Civic Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_Arena_(Pittsburgh) "Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)")'s capacity was increased to meet NHL requirements for a franchise. The arena served as the Penguins' home arena from 1967 to 2010. A contest was held where 700 of 26,000 entries picked "Penguins" as the team's nickname, sharing its nickname with the [athletic department](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youngstown_State_Penguins "Youngstown State Penguins") of the newly named [Youngstown State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youngstown_State_University "Youngstown State University") in nearby [Youngstown, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youngstown,_Ohio "Youngstown, Ohio"). (Youngstown is part of the Penguins' territorial rights to this day, though they did briefly share them with the [Cleveland Barons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Barons_(NHL) "Cleveland Barons (NHL)") in the mid-1970s.) Mark Peters had the winning entry (which was inspired because the team was to play in the "Igloo", the nickname of the Pittsburgh Civic Arena),[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-PenguinsHistoryNHLcom-7)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-8) a logo was chosen that had a penguin in front of a triangle, which symbolized the " [Golden Triangle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Triangle_(Pittsburgh) "Golden Triangle (Pittsburgh)")" of downtown Pittsburgh.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-PenguinsHistoryNHLcom-7)[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-9) The Penguins' first general manager, [Jack Riley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Riley_(ice_hockey,_born_1919) "Jack Riley (ice hockey, born 1919)"), opened the first pre-season camp for the franchise in [Brantford, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brantford,_Ontario "Brantford, Ontario"),[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-10) on September 13, 1967, playing the franchise's first exhibition match in Brantford against the [Philadelphia Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers") on September 23, 1967. Restrictive rules which kept most major talent with the existing "Original Six" teams hampered the Penguins, along with the rest of the expansion teams.

"Cleveland Barons (NHL)") in the mid-1970s.) Mark Peters had the winning entry (which was inspired because the team was to play in the "Igloo", the nickname of the Pittsburgh Civic Arena),[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-PenguinsHistoryNHLcom-7)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-8) a logo was chosen that had a penguin in front of a triangle, which symbolized the " [Golden Triangle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_Triangle_(Pittsburgh) "Golden Triangle (Pittsburgh)")" of downtown Pittsburgh.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-PenguinsHistoryNHLcom-7)[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-9) The Penguins' first general manager, [Jack Riley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Riley_(ice_hockey,_born_1919) "Jack Riley (ice hockey, born 1919)"), opened the first pre-season camp for the franchise in [Brantford, Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brantford,_Ontario "Brantford, Ontario"),[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-10) on September 13, 1967, playing the franchise's first exhibition match in Brantford against the [Philadelphia Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers") on September 23, 1967. Restrictive rules which kept most major talent with the existing "Original Six" teams hampered the Penguins, along with the rest of the expansion teams. Beyond aging sniper [Andy Bathgate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Bathgate "Andy Bathgate"), all-star defenseman [Leo Boivin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_Boivin "Leo Boivin") (who had begun his professional career with the Hornets) and [New York Rangers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers")' veteran [Earl Ingarfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earl_Ingarfield,_Sr. "Earl Ingarfield, Sr."), a cast of former minor leaguers largely manned the first Penguins' team. Several players played for the Hornets the previous season: Bathgate, wingers [Val Fonteyne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Val_Fonteyne "Val Fonteyne") and [Ab McDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ab_McDonald "Ab McDonald"), and goaltenders [Hank Bassen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hank_Bassen "Hank Bassen") and [Joe Daley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Daley_(ice_hockey) "Joe Daley (ice hockey)"). [George Sullivan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Sullivan_(ice_hockey) "George Sullivan (ice hockey)") was named the head coach for the club's first two seasons, and McDonald was named the team's first captain.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-History2010-11) On October 11, 1967, league president [Clarence Campbell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Campbell "Clarence Campbell") and McGregor jointly dropped the ceremonial first puck of the Penguins' opening home game against the [Montreal Canadiens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreal_Canadiens "Montreal Canadiens").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-Steel_City_Legend-5) On October 21, 1967, they became the first team from the expansion class to defeat an Original Six team, as they defeated the Chicago Black Hawks 4–2. However, the Penguins went 27–34–13 and finished in fifth place in the West Division, missing the playoffs and ending with the third-worst record in the league. The team's best player proved to be longtime [Cleveland Barons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Barons_(1937%E2%80%9373) "Cleveland Barons (1937–73)") AHL goaltender [Les Binkley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Binkley "Les Binkley"), who recorded a 2.88 [goals-against average](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goals-against_average "Goals-against average") and was second in the league with six shutouts. Defensive winger [Ken Schinkel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ken_Schinkel "Ken Schinkel") won the team's sole league honor, being named to represent the Penguins in the [NHL All-Star Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/21st_National_Hockey_League_All-Star_Game "21st National Hockey League All-Star Game"). Bathgate led the team in scoring with 59 points but retired at season's end. McDonald, who led the team in goals and was second in team scoring, was also gone at season's end, traded to the [St. Louis Blues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Blues "St. Louis Blues") in exchange for center [Lou Angotti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Angotti "Lou Angotti").[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-History2016-6) The [next season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1968%E2%80%9369_NHL_season "1968–69 NHL season") saw the team slip in the standings amid a sharp drop in form by Binkley, into sixth place and with the league's worst record. Several changes were made to improve the team, resulting in Boivin and several others being traded, and new players – including longtime future Penguins star [Jean Pronovost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Pronovost "Jean Pronovost") – making their debuts. No captain was named to replace McDonald; the team went with four alternate captains. #### Triumph of playoff

in 1992 and 1993 at the [Richfield Coliseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richfield_Coliseum "Richfield Coliseum") (this is not unlike the [Cleveland Cavaliers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") of the [NBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association") playing an annual pre-season game in Pittsburgh;[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-99) the [Philadelphia 76ers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") used the Civic Arena as a second home in the early 1970s).[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-100) [![See caption](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/UPMCLemieux.png/250px-UPMCLemieux.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:UPMCLemieux.png) The UPMC Lemieux Sports Complex under construction in [Cranberry Township, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cranberry_Township,_Butler_County,_Pennsylvania "Cranberry Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania"), in April 2015. The complex opened in August 2015, and is used by the Penguins as their practice facility. From 1995 to 2015, the [IceoPlex at Southpointe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IceoPlex_at_Southpointe "IceoPlex at Southpointe") in the South Hills suburbs served as the team's practice facility. [Robert Morris University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Morris_University "Robert Morris University")'s [84 Lumber Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/84_Lumber_Arena "84 Lumber Arena") has served as a secondary practice facility for the team. During the franchise's first pre-season training camp and pre-season exhibition games, the [Brantford Civic Centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brantford_Civic_Centre "Brantford Civic Centre") in Brantford, Ontario, served as its home,[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-101) and by the 1970s and continuing through the 1980s, the team was using the suburban [Rostraver Ice Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rostraver_Ice_Garden "Rostraver Ice Garden") for training. In August 2015, the Penguins and the [University of Pittsburgh Medical Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Medical_Center "University of Pittsburgh Medical Center") (UPMC) opened the UPMC Lemieux Sports Complex, combining a new team practice and training facility with a UPMC Sports Medicine treatment and research complex, in suburban [Cranberry Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cranberry_Township,_Butler_County,_Pennsylvania "Cranberry Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania") near the interchange between [Interstate 79](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_79 "Interstate 79") and [Pennsylvania Route 228](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_Route_228 "Pennsylvania Route 228").[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-LSM-102) The twin rink facility replaced both the IceoPlex at Southpointe and the 84 Lumber Arena as the Penguins' regular practice facility, freeing up Consol Energy Center for other events on days the Penguins are not scheduled to play.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-103) As with most other NHL arenas, the Penguins make use of a [goal horn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_horn#Use_in_sports "Air horn") whenever the team scores a goal at home. It is also played just before the beginning of a home game, and after a Penguins victory. Their current goal horn made by [Nathan Manufacturing, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathan_Manufacturing,_Inc. "Nathan Manufacturing, Inc.") and introduced in 2005 to coincide with Sidney Crosby joining the team, was used at both the Civic Arena and Consol Energy Center.[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-104)[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-105) ### Minor league affiliates The Penguins have two minor league affiliates assigned to their team. The Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins, their AHL affiliate, have played in [Wilkes-Barre Township, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilkes-Barre_Township,_Pennsylvania "Wilkes-Barre Township, Pennsylvania"), since 1999. The Penguins also have a secondary affiliate in the [ECHL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECHL "ECHL"), the [Wheeling Nailers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheeling_Nailers "Wheeling Nailers"), which they have been associated with since the start of the [2000–01 ECHL season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000%E2%80%9301_ECHL_season "2000–01 ECHL season").[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-106) ### Fanbase [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Iceburgh.jpg/250px-Iceburgh.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Iceburgh.jpg) Iceburgh, the mascot of the Pittsburgh Penguins Despite Pittsburgh's long history with hockey and a small but loyal fanbase, the Penguins struggled with fan support early on in its history, at times averaging only 6,000 fans per game when Civic Arena had a seating capacity of over 16,000. Fan support was so low by the team's first bankruptcy that the NHL had no problem with the team being moved, something that would change decades later when the team faced another relocation threat. While the drafting of Mario

question: Which NHL division do the Penguins play in?
answer: The Penguins play in the Metropolitan Division of the NHL.

during the Penguins' victory parade.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Sidney_Crosby_%2827596105842%29.jpg/250px-Sidney_Crosby_%2827596105842%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sidney_Crosby_(27596105842).jpg) Crosby with the Stanley Cup during the Penguins' victory parade. In the [playoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Stanley_Cup_playoffs "2016 Stanley Cup playoffs"), the Penguins defeated the Rangers in a 4–1 series, the Capitals 4–2 and the Lightning 4–3 to win the Eastern Conference championship, advancing to the [Stanley Cup Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Stanley_Cup_Final "2016 Stanley Cup Final") against the [San Jose Sharks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose_Sharks "San Jose Sharks").[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-49) On June 12, 2016, the Penguins defeated the Sharks in a 4–2 series to win their fourth Stanley Cup title. Captain Sidney Crosby was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-50) The Penguins opened their 50th anniversary season in the NHL as defending Stanley Cup champions, raising their commemorative banner on October 13, 2016, in a shootout victory over Washington.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-51) The Penguins faced the Columbus Blue Jackets in the opening round of the [2017 playoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Stanley_Cup_playoffs "2017 Stanley Cup playoffs"), defeating them in five games. In the second round, they played against their divisional rival, Washington, and faced them for the second-straight year in the same round, winning a seven-game series. In the conference finals, the Penguins eliminated the Ottawa Senators in seven games to advance to the [Stanley Cup Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Stanley_Cup_Final "2017 Stanley Cup Final"), where they faced the [Nashville Predators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville_Predators "Nashville Predators"). The Penguins won the first two games of the series and then lost the next two matchups before dominating the fifth and the sixth games of the series to win the Stanley Cup for the second straight year. Penguins to their first playoff appearance in six years. Change came for the Penguins on October 18, 2006, when Evgeni Malkin made his NHL debut. He set the modern NHL record with a goal in each of his first six games. Malkin would record points in 16 consecutive games.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-34) The Penguins finished the [2006–07 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_NHL_season "2006–07 NHL season") in fifth place in the Eastern Conference with a record of 47–24–11, totaling 105 points, only two points behind the Atlantic Division winners, the New Jersey Devils. It was the franchise's first 100-point season in 11 years and represented an enormous 47-point leap from the previous season. In the first round of the [2007 playoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Stanley_Cup_playoffs "2007 Stanley Cup playoffs") the eventual Stanley Cup runners-up, the Ottawa Senators, defeated the Penguins 4–1. At the season's end, rookies Malkin and Jordan Staal were finalists for the Calder Memorial Trophy, awarded to the Rookie of the Year, which Malkin won. On March 13, 2007, Pennsylvania's governor [Ed Rendell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Rendell "Ed Rendell"), [Allegheny County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_County,_Pennsylvania "Allegheny County, Pennsylvania") chief executive [Dan Onorato](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Onorato "Dan Onorato"), Pittsburgh's mayor [Luke Ravenstahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luke_Ravenstahl "Luke Ravenstahl") and Mario Lemieux of the Penguins ownership group announced an agreement had been reached among the parties to build the long-sought arena. The completion of [Consol Energy Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena "PPG Paints Arena") guaranteed that the Penguins would remain in Pittsburgh. Following the announcement of the plan, the Lemieux ownership group announced they no longer had plans to sell the team. On June 8, 2007, a $325 million [bond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bond_(finance) "Bond (finance)") was issued, and the Penguins signed a 30-year [lease](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lease "Lease") on September 19, binding them to the city of Pittsburgh through 2040.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-35) After a mediocre start to the [2007–08 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_NHL_season "2007–08 NHL season"), Crosby and starting goaltender Marc-Andre Fleury were both injured long-term due to high right ankle sprains. In their absence, the team flourished because of the play and leadership of Malkin. On April 2, 2008, the Penguins clinched the Atlantic Division title – their first division title in 10 years – with a 4–2 win against rivals the Philadelphia Flyers. Malkin finished the season with 106 points for second place in the league and finished as a finalist for the [Hart Memorial Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hart_Memorial_Trophy "Hart Memorial Trophy"). The team launched into their first extended playoff run in many years, beating Ottawa 4–0, defeating the New York Rangers 4–1 and then defeating the Philadelphia Flyers 4–1 to clinch the [Prince of Wales Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_of_Wales_Trophy "Prince of Wales Trophy"). Pittsburgh lost the [2008 Stanley Cup Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Stanley_Cup_Final "2008 Stanley Cup Final") to the Detroit Red Wings in six games, finishing the playoffs with a 14–6 record. Crosby finished the playoffs with 27 points (6 goals and 21 assists in 20 games), tying [Conn Smythe Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conn_Smythe_Trophy "Conn Smythe Trophy")-winner [Henrik Zetterberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henrik_Zetterberg "Henrik Zetterberg") (13 goals and 14 assists in 22 games) for the playoff scoring lead. [![Photograph if Crosy, Bill Guerin and Chris Kunitz talking on ice during a game](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Sidney_Crosby_with_Bill_Guerin_and_Chris_Kunitz_2009-06-06.JPG/250px-Sidney_Crosby_with_Bill_Guerin_and_Chris_Kunitz_2009-06-06.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sidney_Crosby_with_Bill_Guerin_and_Chris_Kunitz_2009-06-06.JPG) Crosby, [Bill Guerin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Guerin "Bill Guerin"), and [Chris Kunitz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Kunitz "Chris Kunitz") during the [2009 Stanley Cup Final](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Stanley_Cup_Final "2009 Stanley Cup Final"). The Penguins defeated the [Detroit

question: In which NHL conference are the Penguins?
answer: The Pittsburgh Penguins are in the Metropolitan Division of the Eastern Conference in the NHL.

contexts.text: in deferred salary, making him the team's largest individual creditor. He proposed recovering this money by converting it into equity – enough to give him controlling interest. He also vowed to keep the team in Pittsburgh. The NHL and the courts agreed, and Lemieux (with help from supermarket tycoon [Ronald Burkle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Burkle "Ronald Burkle")) assumed control on September 3, 1999, saving the franchise for the second time.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-History2016-6) Lemieux again shocked the hockey world by announcing at a press conference on December 8, 2000, his intentions to return to the Penguins as an active player. On December 27, 2000, Lemieux stepped onto NHL ice for the first time in 44 months, officially becoming the first player–owner in NHL history. Lemieux helped lead the Penguins deep into the [2001 playoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Stanley_Cup_playoffs "2001 Stanley Cup playoffs"), highlighted by an overtime victory against the Buffalo Sabres in game 7 of the second round. Darius Kasparaitis scored the series-clinching goal to advance the Penguins to the conference finals, where they lost in five games to the New Jersey Devils.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-History2016-6) #### Rebuilding (2001–2005) [![Photograph of goaltender Marc-Andre Fleury waering his face mask](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Marc-Andre_Fleury_2014-12-12.JPG/250px-Marc-Andre_Fleury_2014-12-12.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Marc-Andre_Fleury_2014-12-12.JPG) [Marc-Andre Fleury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc-Andr%C3%A9_Fleury "Marc-André Fleury") was drafted first overall in [2003](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_NHL_entry_draft "2003 NHL entry draft") by the Penguins. The Penguins' attendance had dwindled in the late 1990s. In 1998–99, the club had an average attendance of 14,825 at home games, the lowest it had been since Lemieux's rookie year.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-attendance-19) Reducing revenue on top of the previous bankruptcy necessitated salary shedding. The biggest salary move was the trading of superstar Jaromir Jagr to the Washington Capitals in the summer of 2001. The Penguins missed the playoffs for the first time in 12 years in [2002](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001%E2%80%9302_NHL_season "2001–02 NHL season"), finishing in a tie for third-to-last in their conference. The [following season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_NHL_season "2002–03 NHL season") they finished second-last. In the [2003 NHL entry draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003_NHL_entry_draft "2003 NHL entry draft"), the Penguins selected goaltender [Marc-Andre Fleury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc-Andr%C3%A9_Fleury "Marc-André Fleury") with the first overall pick.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-20)[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-21) The [2003–04 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_NHL_season "2003–04 NHL season") was an ordeal with Lemieux missing all but 24 regular season games with a hip injury, and attendance dipping to an average of 11,877 (the lowest average of any NHL team), with just one sellout.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-attendance-19) As the season progressed, the Penguins signed new head coach (and former Penguins' player and commentator) [Eddie Olczyk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddie_Olczyk "Eddie Olczyk") and opted not to include Fleury in the lineup for the bulk of the season. This culminated in the worst record in the NHL, with the team winning just 23 games. As in the 1980s, the Penguins' struggles were fortuitously concurrent with a string of NHL entry draft classes that would yield multiple world-class talents. The Penguins lost out on the first overall pick for the [2004 NHL entry draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_NHL_entry_draft "2004 NHL entry draft") ( [Alexander Ovechkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Ovechkin "Alexander Ovechkin")), which went to the Washington Capitals. However, Ovechkin's countryman, center [Evgeni Malkin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evgeni_Malkin "Evgeni Malkin"), was similarly highly regarded, and Pittsburgh took him with the second overall pick. However, a transfer dispute between the NHL and the [International Ice Hockey Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Ice_Hockey_Federation "International Ice Hockey Federation") (IIHF) delayed his Pittsburgh debut.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-Malkindraft-22) By this

winning the [Maurice "Rocket" Richard Trophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_%22Rocket%22_Richard_Trophy "Maurice \"Rocket\" Richard Trophy") as the NHL season's leading goalscorer. The Penguins, seeded fourth in the East, began their title defense, defeating the Ottawa Senators in six games. In the next round, the Penguins faced the Montreal Canadiens. The teams swapped wins in the series en route to the decisive game 7, which the Penguins lost 5–2, ending their season and their tenure at Mellon Arena.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-37) #### New arena and injuries (2010–2015) [![Photograph of the exterior of the Console Energy Center](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg) Outside of [Consol Energy Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena "PPG Paints Arena") (now PPG Paints Arena) in March 2010 before it officially opened.[![Photograph of the Pittsburgh Penguins and Washington Capitals on the ice before the 2011 NHL Winter Classic in Pittsburgh at Heinz Field](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/2011_Winter_Classic_player_entrance.jpg/250px-2011_Winter_Classic_player_entrance.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2011_Winter_Classic_player_entrance.jpg) The Penguins hosted the [Washington Capitals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") at [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field") during the [2011 Winter Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_NHL_Winter_Classic "2011 NHL Winter Classic"). In [2010–11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_NHL_season "2010–11 NHL season"), the Penguins played their first game in [Consol Energy Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consol_Energy_Center "Consol Energy Center"). On February 11, 2011, the [Pittsburgh Penguins–New York Islanders brawl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins%E2%80%93New_York_Islanders_brawl "Pittsburgh Penguins–New York Islanders brawl") took place.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-brawl2011-38) A season-ending concussion suffered by Crosby and a knee injury to Malkin marred the season. The team left early in the playoffs, blowing a 3–1 series lead to [Tampa Bay Lightning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Lightning "Tampa Bay Lightning"), with Fleury's goaltending called into question.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-39) With Crosby still sidelined with [post-concussion syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-concussion_syndrome "Post-concussion syndrome"), at the start of the [2011–12 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_NHL_season "2011–12 NHL season"), Malkin led the Penguins' top line and dominated league scoring. He finished with 50 goals and 109 points as the Penguins earned 51 wins on the season. With Malkin's Art Ross-winning performance, and Crosby's late-season return from injury, the Penguins headed into the [2012 playoffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Stanley_Cup_playoffs "2012 Stanley Cup playoffs") with high hopes of making a significant Stanley Cup run. However, their cross-state rivals, the Philadelphia Flyers, defeated the highly favored Penguins in six games.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-40) Malkin was later awarded the Hart Memorial Trophy and [Lester B. Pearson award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Lindsay_Award "Ted Lindsay Award"). Following the Penguins' disappointing playoff exit, general manager Ray Shero made changes to the team at the [2012 NHL entry draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_NHL_entry_draft "2012 NHL entry draft") for the upcoming [2012–13 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NHL_season "2012–13 NHL season").[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-41)[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-42) During the [lockout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NHL_lockout "2012–13 NHL lockout")-shortened 2012–13 season, the Penguins again fought through serious injury. At the end of the regular season, they finished atop the Eastern Conference, matching up against the New York Islanders in round one. The Penguins defeated the Islanders in six games, with Fleury struggling once again. The team then dispatched the Ottawa Senators in five games before being swept in the conference finals by the Boston Bruins, scoring just two goals in the entire four-game sweep. On June 13, 2013, Malkin signed an eight-year contract extension worth an annual average of $9.5 million.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-43) [![Photograph of Phil Kessel](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Phil_Kessel_2017-06-08.jpg/250px-Phil_Kessel_2017-06-08.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Phil_Kessel_2017-06-08.jpg) On July 1, 2015, the Penguins acquired right-winger [Phil Kessel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil_Kessel "Phil Kessel") in a multi-player deal. In the [2013–14 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_NHL_season "2013–14 NHL season"), the Penguins suffered numerous injuries throughout the campaign. Despite the adversity, the Penguins won the realigned, eight-team [Metropolitan Division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_Division "Metropolitan Division"),

- [Marian Hossa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mari%C3%A1n_Hossa "Marián Hossa") - [Jarome Iginla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jarome_Iginla "Jarome Iginla") - [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux") - [Joe Mullen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Mullen "Joe Mullen") - [Larry Murphy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Murphy_(ice_hockey) "Larry Murphy (ice hockey)") - [Mark Recchi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Recchi "Mark Recchi") - [Luc Robitaille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luc_Robitaille "Luc Robitaille") - [Bryan Trottier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryan_Trottier "Bryan Trottier") - [Sergei Zubov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergei_Zubov "Sergei Zubov") **Builders** - [Scotty Bowman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scotty_Bowman "Scotty Bowman") - [Herb Brooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herb_Brooks "Herb Brooks") - [Bob Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Johnson_(ice_hockey,_born_1931) "Bob Johnson (ice hockey, born 1931)") - [Craig Patrick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craig_Patrick "Craig Patrick") - [Jim Rutherford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Rutherford "Jim Rutherford") #### Team captains [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Sidney_Crosby_2016-04-28_2.JPG/250px-Sidney_Crosby_2016-04-28_2.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sidney_Crosby_2016-04-28_2.JPG) The team's current captain, Sidney Crosby, during a playoff game in 2016. All the players who have served as team captain with the Penguins franchise - [Ab McDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ab_McDonald "Ab McDonald"), 1967–1968 - [Earl Ingarfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earl_Ingarfield_Sr. "Earl Ingarfield Sr."), 1968–1969 - [Ron Schock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Schock "Ron Schock"), 1973–1977 - [Jean Pronovost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Pronovost "Jean Pronovost"), 1977–1978 - [Orest Kindrachuk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orest_Kindrachuk "Orest Kindrachuk"), 1978–1981 - [Randy Carlyle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randy_Carlyle "Randy Carlyle"), 1981–1984 - [Mike Bullard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Bullard_(ice_hockey) "Mike Bullard (ice hockey)"), 1984–1986 - [Terry Ruskowski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_Ruskowski "Terry Ruskowski"), 1986–1987 - [Dan Frawley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Frawley_(ice_hockey) "Dan Frawley (ice hockey)"), 1987 - [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux"), 1987–1994, 1995–1997, 2001–2006 - [Ron Francis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Francis "Ron Francis"), 1995,[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-126) 1997–1998 - [Jaromir Jagr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jarom%C3%ADr_J%C3%A1gr "Jaromír Jágr"), 1998–2001 - [Sidney Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Crosby "Sidney Crosby"), 2007–present ## Franchise records Further information: [List of Pittsburgh Penguins records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Penguins_records "List of Pittsburgh Penguins records") ### Scoring leaders [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kris_Letang_2017-10-11_17240.jpg/250px-Kris_Letang_2017-10-11_17240.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kris_Letang_2017-10-11_17240.jpg) [Kris Letang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kris_Letang "Kris Letang") holds the franchise's all-time points record for a defenseman. The rivalry exists both due to divisional alignment and geographic location, as both teams play in [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"). The Flyers lead the head-to-head record with a 153–98–30 record.[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-132) However, the Penguins eliminated the Flyers from the playoffs in 2008 and 2009 and were eliminated by them from the playoffs in 2012, strengthening the rivalry. Three years later, the Flyers won the sixth playoff meeting between the clubs to advance to the conference semifinals.[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins#cite_note-133) The franchises have met seven times in the playoffs, with the Flyers winning four series (1989 division finals, 4–3; 1997 conference quarterfinals, 4–1; 2000 conference semifinals, 4–2; and 2012 conference quarterfinals, 4–2) and the Penguins winning three (2008 conference finals, 4–1;

question: Which organization operates four museums in Pittsburgh?
answer: The Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh operates four museums in Pittsburgh.

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#bodyContent) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg/70px-Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg.png)\\ Photograph a historic site, help Wikipedia, and win a prize. Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"): ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png)[40°26′34″N79°57′2″W﻿ / ﻿40.44278°N 79.95056°W﻿ / 40.44278; -79.95056](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh¶ms=40_26_34_N_79_57_2_W_region:US_type:landmark) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia United States historic place | | | Carnegie Institute and Library | | [U.S. National Register of Historic Places](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") | | [U.S. Historic district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historic_districts_in_the_United_States "Historic districts in the United States")
[Contributing property](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contributing_property "Contributing property") | | [Pittsburgh Landmark – PHLF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_History_and_Landmarks_Foundation_Historic_Landmarks "List of Pittsburgh History and Landmarks Foundation Historic Landmarks") | | | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Carnegie_Music_Hall_Pittsburgh.JPG/330px-Carnegie_Music_Hall_Pittsburgh.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Music_Hall_Pittsburgh.JPG)
The Carnegie Institute serves as the headquarters of the Carnegie Museums | **Carnegie Museums of Pittsburgh** is a [nonprofit organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonprofit_organization "Nonprofit organization") that operates four museums in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), Pennsylvania, United States. The organization is headquartered in the **Carnegie Institute and Library** complex in the [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood of Pittsburgh. The Carnegie Institute complex, which includes the original museum, recital hall, and library, was added to the [National Register of Historic Places](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") on March 30, 1979. ## Portfolio \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: Portfolio")\] Two of the Carnegie museums, the [Carnegie Museum of Natural History](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museum_of_Natural_History "Carnegie Museum of Natural History") and the [Carnegie Museum of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museum_of_Art "Carnegie Museum of Art"), are both located in the Carnegie Institute and Library complex in Oakland, a landmark building listed on the [National Register of Historic Places](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of Historic Places") (ref #79002158, added 1979). It also houses the Carnegie Music Hall and the main branch of the [Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh").[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-3) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Carnegie_Library_Free_to_the_People.jpg/250px-Carnegie_Library_Free_to_the_People.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Library_Free_to_the_People.jpg) Motto "Free to the people" above the Carnegie Library entrance [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") donated the library and the buildings. With the goal of inspiring people to do good for themselves and their communities, the terms for donations required communities to support them in exchange for the building and initial investment by Carnegie. The words "free to the people" inscribed above the entrance of the [Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Library_of_Pittsburgh "Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh") illustrate his vision.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-Gangewere-4) The other two museums, [The Andy Warhol Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Andy_Warhol_Museum "The Andy Warhol Museum") and the [Kamin Science Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kamin_Science_Center "Kamin Science Center"), are located in separate facilities on Pittsburgh's [North Shore](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Shore_(Pittsburgh) "North Shore (Pittsburgh)").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-5) ## Andy Warhol Museum \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh&action=edit§ion=2 "Edit section: Andy Warhol Museum")\] Main article: [The Andy Warhol Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Andy_Warhol_Museum "The Andy Warhol Museum") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Andy_Warhol_Museum%2C_Pittsburgh%2C_2015-06-17%2C_01.jpg/250px-Andy_Warhol_Museum%2C_Pittsburgh%2C_2015-06-17%2C_01.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andy_Warhol_Museum,_Pittsburgh,_2015-06-17,_01.jpg) Andy Warhol Museum Opened on May 15, 1994, the [Andy Warhol Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Warhol_Museum "Andy Warhol Museum") is the first museum to exclusively focus on an American postwar artist.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-6) The building which houses the Andy Warhol Museum was originally built in 1911 for industrial purposes, but was redesigned for the museum by architect [Richard Gluckman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gluckman_Tang_Architects "Gluckman Tang Architects"). The museum currently has seven floors of gallery and exhibition space as well as an underground education studio and conservation lab.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Museums_of_Pittsburgh#cite_note-7) Warhol's primary artistic technique was silkscreen pop art, which he gained notoriety for in the early 1960s. The serial images derived from the culture's consumerism and conception of beauty are reified in a form of art which represent the

changing landscape of the museum world, and Carnegie Museums, McCloskey says, is the ideal place to learn. “As the museums know, making collections more accessible is how you bring the public into your institutions and also how you generate new knowledge,” says McCloskey. “The museums have extraordinary collections, and we’ve got students who are ready, able, and willing to pursue research.” Those same students, guided by Peters, can also help the museums see their future through the fresh eyes of the next generation of museum visitors and supporters. Starting in the spring, Peters will teach an introduction to museums course at Pitt, using the four Carnegie Museums as a living laboratory. She’ll also supervise a small team of student interns working across the museums. “Because Carnegie Museums includes four distinct museums with different holdings and ways of operating, it’s the perfect model,” says Peters. “We’ll explore what is typically an art museum and how does Carnegie Museum of Art navigate that; and what is typically a natural history museum and how does Carnegie Museum of Natural History navigate that, and so on. How do we work together in this sort of older model of classification and separation and move beyond it to connection?” Consider, for example, Egyptian art and artifacts. Even though the objects are from the same location and same time period, notes Peters, Carnegie Museums houses the ancient treasures in two different museums—which share a building—and they’re displayed in completely different ways. “We’ll talk about what this tells us about museums and how they communicate messages,” says Peters. “How display lighting, what museums call objects, and how much information you put around objects creates an idea of what those objects are.” It’s likely the students will even help the museum prototype elements of exhibitions, bringing the visitor into the process from the start, says Peters. As these kinds of relationships continue to build—among the museums and between the museums and other organizations, such as Pitt—it’s all about changing the conversation, Parker says. “These catalyst positions haven’t been created so much to do something for us as to influence and shape the way we do most things we do.” Also in this issue: The Elevation of Everyday Design · Taking its Bow · Art of the Now · Inside the Cloud Factory · President’s Note · NewsWorthy · Artistic License: In Full Light · Travel Log · The Big Picture Copyright © 2017 CARNEGIE Magazine. We’ve put together an extensive list of must-visit attractions worth adding to…\\ \\ Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/top-things-to-do/)[![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Tours & Sightseeing \\ \\ ​However you like to roll, Pittsburgh is sure to have the sightseeing option for you.\\ \\ Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/tours-sightseeing/)[![Wide angle view of PNC Park baseball field. The Pittsburgh skyline is visible beyond the stadium](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Pittsburgh Sports \\ \\ In Pittsburgh, we bleed black and gold.\\ \\ Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/pittsburgh-sports-teams/)[![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Restaurants & Culinary \\ \\ Global cuisine spanning 90 unique neighborhoods\\ \\ Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/restaurants-culinary/) # Museums From history, art, science, sports and more, Pittsburgh museums offer much to be explored. If you love art, culture, and learning, Pittsburgh is a great place to explore. With our wide range of museums and galleries, there are endless must-do items to add to your agenda. [View All Pittsburgh Museums](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/arts-culture/museums/#jlview-all-pittsburgh-museums) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) [iframe](https://202dc309ba98c632b0ee096cacd2d998.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-45/html/container.html) Whether you're looking for rainy day activities or seeking [family-friendly things to do](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/family-fun/), Pittsburgh's museums offer diverse perspectives, engaging exhibits, and interactive galleries. Our museums feature a variety of indoor fun during the [colder months](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/plan-your-trip/weather/). There are no shortage of galleries or exhibits for [sports lovers](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/pittsburgh-sports-teams/), [foodies](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/restaurants-culinary/), history experts, science enthusiasts, and [art connoisseurs](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/arts-culture/visual-arts/). ## Discover a Museum for Every Interest ### Find Your Inner Artist Exploring the Local Arts Scene Explore [Pittsburgh's arts and culture scene](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/arts-culture/) with a trip to some of our most popular attractions. Browse through a diverse array of paintings, sculptures, and more at locations such as [Carnegie Museum of Art](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/insiders-guide-carnegie-museums-of-art-and-natural-history/), [The Frick Pittsburgh](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/the-frick-pittsburgh/), and [The Westmoreland Museum of American Art](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/directory/the-westmoreland-museum-of-american-art-event-meeting-venues/). Marvel at iconic and colorful works at [Andy Warhol Museum](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/insiders-guide-the-andy-warhol-museum/), or stroll through immersive installations at [Mattress Factory](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/directory/mattress-factory-museum-of-contemporary-art/). ### Uncover Multiple Layers of History Plan for a history-filled itinerary in Pittsburgh, where fascinating treasures and artifacts await. Make your way to Heinz History Center, which features a wide range of Smithsonian objects, as well as an exhibits about the Underground Railroad, Mister Rogers, and Pittsburgh's contributions to American history. Dinosaur aficionados and geology buffs will enjoy spotting one-of-a-kind specimens and gems at [Carnegie Museum of Natural History](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/carnegie-museum-of-natural-history/). Don't miss making a stop at [Fort Pitt Museum](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/directory/fort-pitt-museum/), discovering Western Pennsylvania's impact on a historic events such as the American Revolution and the development of Pittsburgh.
