Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"): ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png)[40°27′12″N79°58′47″W﻿ / ﻿40.453250°N 79.979770°W﻿ / 40.453250; -79.979770](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Pittsburgh_Opera¶ms=40.45325_N_79.97977_W_) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Pittsburgh's Opera company and venue | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/PittsburghOperaBuilding.jpg/250px-PittsburghOperaBuilding.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PittsburghOperaBuilding.jpg)
The Pittsburgh Opera Building | Pittsburgh Opera [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/BenedumCenterForThePerformingArts.jpg/330px-BenedumCenterForThePerformingArts.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BenedumCenterForThePerformingArts.jpg) The opera's main performance venue, the [Benedum Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedum_Center "Benedum Center") **Pittsburgh Opera** is an American [opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opera "Opera") company based in [Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh,_Pennsylvania "Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania"). Pittsburgh Opera gives performances in several venues, primarily at the [Benedum Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedum_Center "Benedum Center"), with other performances at the [Pittsburgh Creative and Performing Arts School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Creative_and_Performing_Arts_School "Pittsburgh Creative and Performing Arts School") (CAPA) Theater. [Pittsburgh Opera headquarters](http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_592946.html) [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20090907070038/http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_592946.html) 2009-09-07 at the [Wayback Machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayback_Machine "Wayback Machine") is located in the former [George Westinghouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Westinghouse "George Westinghouse") [Air Brake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westinghouse_Air_Brake_Company "Westinghouse Air Brake Company") Factory, 2425 Liberty Avenue, in the [Strip District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strip_District,_Pittsburgh "Strip District, Pittsburgh"). Pittsburgh Opera has been awarded LEED Silver Certification by the [U.S. Green Building Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Green_Building_Council "U.S. Green Building Council")[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-2) and is the first ["green" opera company](http://www.pittsburghopera.org/pages/green-initiative) in the U.S. in the Operations and Maintenance Category. Pittsburgh Opera's headquarters is also the oldest green building in Pittsburgh. ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Opera&action=edit§ion=1 "Edit section: History")\] Pittsburgh Opera was established in 1939 as the Pittsburgh Opera Company and is the eighth-oldest opera company in the United States. The company was founded by five women who established the Pittsburgh Opera Society in 1939, making possible the inaugural performance of [Offenbach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Offenbach "Jacques Offenbach")'s _[Les Contes d'Hoffmann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Contes_d%27Hoffmann "Les Contes d'Hoffmann")_ at the [Carnegie Music Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Music_Hall "Carnegie Music Hall") in March 1940.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-3) The first director of the company was Richard Karp, from 1942 to 1977. His daughter Barbara Karp took over her father's duties during his final illness. James DeBlasis then served as interim artistic director after the resignation of Barbara Karp. In 1983, [Tito Capobianco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tito_Capobianco "Tito Capobianco") became Pittsburgh Opera's general director, holding this position until 1997.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-Croan1-4) From 1997 to 2000, Capobianco was the company's artistic director, before leaving in 2000.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-5) Mark Weinstein became general director of Pittsburgh Opera in 1999, after starting as executive director in 1997.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-Croan1-4) During his tenure, he presided over an increase in the company's endowment from US $4 million to US $16 million, as well as the retirement of US $2.5 million in debt.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-6) Weinstein also presided over the addition of an extra production during the company season, 5 productions as opposed to 4, from the 2001-2002 season to the 2003-2004 season.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-7) Weinstein announced his resignation as Pittsburgh Opera's general director effective February 1, 2008.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Opera#cite_note-8) Artistic Director Christopher Hahn was appointed as [General Director](http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1452015/pittsburgh_opera_appoints_christopher_hahn_its_general_director/index.html) in June 2008. During [Christopher Hahn’s](https://www.pittsburghopera.org/resident-artists/faculty-administration) tenure as General Director, the company’s repertoire expanded considerably to include Baroque and many contemporary works. In 2017 Pittsburgh Opera produced its first world premiere, The Summer King – the [Josh Gibson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Gibson "Josh Gibson") Story. Based on the life and tragic death of the Hall of Fame baseball player who grew up in Pittsburgh and starred for the [Homestead Grays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_Grays "Homestead Grays") and [Pittsburgh Crawfords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Crawfords "Pittsburgh Crawfords"), The Summer King featured bass-baritone Alfred Walker in the

He performed as Idomeneo/ [**afterWARds - Mozart's _Idomeneo_ Reimagined**](https://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/afterwards?hsLang=en), Younger Thompson/ [**Glory Denied**](https://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/glory-denied?hsLang=en), and Parpignol/ [**La bohème**](https://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/la-boheme?hsLang=en). Hailed as having a "beautiful lyric tenor voice" by Opera News, Mr. Chin-Loy holds a BA in Musicology from [Yale University](http://music.yale.edu/), a MM Voice from [Mannes College of Music](https://www.newschool.edu/mannes/), and is a recent gradute from [Indiana University](http://music.indiana.edu/) with a PD in Voice. While at Indiana University he performed the role of Edgardo/ **Lucia di Lammermoor** as well as George Bailey/ **It’s a Wonderful Life** and Tonio/ **La fille du regiment**. He performed with [Mannes Opera](https://www.newschool.edu/mannes/voice-opera/) in the roles of Laurie/ **Little Women** and Bill/ **Flight**. During his time at Yale Mr. Chin-Loy performed the roles of Ferrando/ **Così fan tutte**, Pane/ **La Calisto**, Eurimaco and Amfimono/ **Il ritorno d’Ulisse in patria**, and Count Alberto/ **L’occasione fa il ladro**. In 2017, Mr. Chin-Loy made his Pittsburgh Opera debut as Double Duty Radcliffe in [**The Summer King**](https://www.pittsburghopera.org/show/the-summer-king?hsLang=en). He also sang as an Apprentice Artist with [Santa Fe Opera](https://www.santafeopera.org/) where he covered the role of Astrologer **/The Golden Cockerel**. When Rodolfo, a poet, and Mimì, a young seamstress, meet, the two are drawn into a tumultuous and passionate affair with a love that can only be broken by death. La Bohème will make you laugh, and bring you to tears, with its timeless story and captivating music. Emotional and dramatic, it’s no wonder Puccini’s most celebrated opera has transcended the genre, inspiring both a ballet and the Broadway hit musical RENT. Antony Walker conducts; Kristine McIntyre directs. _These performances are sponsored in part by generous gifts from The Gailliot Fund and Drs. Athan and Lydia Georgiades. # Get to the Point of Pittsburgh History

[Skip Sub Navigation](https://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/visit/fort-pitt/#page_content)

Explore This SectionClose

Discover the world-shaping events that occurred right here in Pittsburgh at the Fort Pitt Museum, located within Point State Park.

The Fort Pitt Museum tells the story of Western Pennsylvania’s pivotal role during the French & Indian War, the American Revolution, and as the birthplace of Pittsburgh through interactive exhibitions, life-like figures, and 18th-century artifacts.

During the summer months, you can witness living history in Point State Park as the Fort Pitt Museum’s colonial reenactors demonstrate how life was lived during the 1700s.

## Hours & Location

- Address: **Point State Park, 601 Commonwealth Pl, Pittsburgh, PA 15222**, in the heart of Downtown Pittsburgh.
- Hours: Daily from **10 a.m. to 5 p.m**.
- Holiday Closures: New Year’s Day, Easter, Thanksgiving, and Christmas.
- Follow the footpath entrance to Point State Park, via Commonwealth Place, crossing under the portal bridge.

## Admission

### **Always Free for Kids!**

Thanks to a transformative gift from longtime supporters Daniel G. and Carole L. Kamin, the Heinz History Center now offers free admission for all kids year-round!

The [Kamin “Free for Kids” Initiative](https://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/families/kamin-family-legacy/) includes free museum entry for all children aged 17 and under and cover admission costs for all school groups.

## Learn More About Fort Pitt Museum

The Fort Pitt Museum, located in historic Point State Park in downtown Pittsburgh, is a two-floor, 12,000-square-foot museum that tells the story of Western Pennsylvania’s pivotal role during the French & Indian War, the American Revolution, and as the birthplace of Pittsburgh.

The strategic location of the fort – at the Forks of the Ohio River – helped to shape the course of American and world history.

First opened in 1969 in a reconstructed bastion, the Fort Pitt Museum provides visitors with a rich understanding of the world-changing events that occurred right here in Western Pennsylvania.

Through interactive exhibitions, life-like historical figures, and recently added artifacts, visitors will learn the important role our region played in shaping the United States.

## What's On at Fort Pitt?

Fort Pitt Museum

Get the inside scoop on featured exhibits and events at the museum.

[What’s On](https://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/whats-on/fort-pitt)

## The Shop at Fort Pitt

The Fort Pitt Museum Shop is your one-stop shop for quirky colonial gifts. The Museum Shop is open 24/7 online, and seven days a week during regular museum hours.

[Explore the Shop](https://shop.heinzhistorycenter.org/collections/fort-pitt-museum)

## Fort Pitt Block House

The Fort Pitt Museum’s historic neighbor is the Fort Pitt Block House, owned and maintained by the Pittsburgh Chapter of the National Society Daughters of the American Revolution. The Block House is not affiliated with the Fort Pitt Museum or the Heinz History Center.

[Learn More](http://www.fortpittblockhouse.com/)

The entrance is located on Reynolds Street where parking is available in our free lot. From downtown Pittsburgh, the Pittsburgh Airport or PA Turnpike, the Frick is reached via the Parkway East (I-376). Exit at #77–Edgewood Swissvale (take the Edgewood ramp), follow Braddock Ave. to Penn Ave. and turn left. Continue four blocks and turn left on South Homewood Ave. Proceed one long block to traffic circle (Reynolds St.) and follow signs to parking lot entrance. **PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION** Pittsburgh Regional Transit buses 67, 69, and 71C\* provide service from downtown Pittsburgh. _\*Starting October 1, 2023, the 71C will terminate in Oakland and no longer serve Uptown and downtown Pittsburgh. Please plan accordingly. [Learn more about the schedule changes on Pittsburgh Regional Transit's website](https://www.rideprt.org/schedules/Service-adjustments/)._ [Get Directions](https://www.google.com/maps?ll=40.446587,-79.902277&z=17&t=m&hl=en-US&gl=IN&mapclient=embed&cid=17850738363559558322) [Public Transportation](https://www.rideprt.org/) Plan Ahead ## Make the Most of Your Visit ##### Exhibitions Explore our museums for world-class permanent and temporary exhibitions [Learn more](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/exhibitions) ##### Tours Enhance your experience with a docent-led tour [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/tours) ##### The Café Enjoy a treat at The Café at the Frick Tuesday–Sunday, 9:30 AM–3 PM [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/cafe) ##### Store Visit the Museum Store for a unique and carefully curated selection of gifts [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/store) ##### Know Before You Go Familiarize yourself with the Frick's visitation guidelines and policies [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/knowbeforeyougo) ##### Accessibility We are committed to offering an inclusive experience for all visitors [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/accessibility) ##### School Visits Let our staff personalize your school group visit [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/school-programs) ##### Group Visits Get information on scheduling a customized group visit [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/groupvisits) Get ready to visit The Frick Pittsburgh ### Download our Mobile Landscape App to prepare for your visit! gender restrooms are located in the Grable Visitor Center, the Education Center, and the Café. Opened in April of 2024, the Frick Art Museum now features an Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)-compliant restroom — an all-gender accessible family space intended to better serve Frick visitors of all ages, identities, and abilities ### Doors Power-assist doors can be found at the Frick Art Museum, the Grable Visitor Center, the Car and Carriage Museum, and the Community Room. ### Families ![Photo of the Scott Family Infant Care Room with a large, comfy yellow chair, warm lighting, and amenities for caretakers and children](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/Files/Admin/Infant-Care-Room_250-min.png) **The Scott Family Infant Care Room** New at the Frick, the Scott Family Infant Care Room was designed as a space for caregivers to tend to their young children during their visit in comfort and privacy. Located in the Grable Visitor Center, the Scott Family Infant Care Room is decorated cheerfully with custom wallpaper designed by local artist Clinton van Gemert, and features a cozy armchair, white noise machine, changing table, and toys for little ones to enjoy. Baby changing stations are located in the Grable Visitor Center, The Frick Art Museum and the Car and Carriage Museum. Strollers are welcome in all buildings on site except Clayton. ### Service Animals Service animals are permitted in all public areas of the museum. Service animals are trained to perform specific tasks for an individual with a disability as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act. Comfort animals, therapy animals, companion animals, or emotional support animals are not service animals as defined by the ADA and are not allowed. The ADA guidelines regarding service animals can be accessed [here.](https://www.ada.gov/service_animals_2010.htm) ### Aides Professional aides accompanying visitors are admitted to Clayton and to ticketed exhibitions at no charge (one aide per guest). To make a reservation for a professional aide, please call us at 412-371-0600 in advance of your visit. ### Sign Language American Sign Language interpreters are available at no charge for tours and programs with advance notice to ensure availability. Requests for an ASL interpreter must be made at least two weeks in advance of the date of the visit by contacting Dalena Collins, Learning and Interpretive Coordinator, at 412-342-4087 or [dcollins@thefrickpittsburgh.org](mailto:dcollins@thefrickpittsburgh.org). Payment for the tour or program must be made in advance. ### Large Print Large print labels are available for visitors to special exhibitions. Labels can be requested at the admissions desk in The Frick Art Museum. ### Membership The Frick offers an ADA Membership for $30 per year for one person and one aide. For a full list of benefits or to join, visit our Membership page [here](https://thefrickpittsburgh.org/membership) or call the membership office at 412-342-4086 or [email us](mailto:membership@thefrickpittsburgh.org?subject=ADA%20Membership%20%7C%20Website%20Inquiry). #### Accessibility Coordinator The Frick’s accessibility coordinator is Ashley Legg, Director of Enterprise & Visitor Services. She can be reached at [alegg@thefrickpittsburgh.org](mailto:alegg@thefrickpittsburgh.org) or 412-342-4064. [![The Frick Pittsburgh Museums and Gardens Logo](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/Files/User/logo.svg)](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/ "The Frick Pittsburgh Museums and Gardens Logo") Keep up to date with news and events from The Frick Pittsburgh newsletter. #### The Frick Pittsburgh 7227 Reynolds St. Pittsburgh, PA 15208 **Hours:** Monday:

contexts.text: for [Pittsburgh Civic Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_Arena_(Pittsburgh) "Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)"), the oldest arena in the NHL (built in 1961).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Nest-13) In an attempt not to use public funding, the Penguins filed for a slots license under the Pennsylvania Gaming Control Board. The Penguins were granted the license, though the decision of which casino company would receive approval was the Gaming Control Board's decision.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-NoBrain-14) The Lemieux Group reached an agreement with [Isle of Capri Casinos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isle_of_Capri_Casinos "Isle of Capri Casinos"), which offered to fully fund a US$290 million arena, if Capri could also construct a $500 million casino nearby.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-NoBrain-14) Other casinos, including [Majestic Star Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Majestic_Star_Casino,_LLC "The Majestic Star Casino, LLC") and [Forest City Enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forest_City_Enterprises "Forest City Enterprises"), also agreed to partially contribute to the arena's funding.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PITG_Wins_Slots_Casino_License_for_North_Side-15) On December 20, 2006, the Gaming Control Board awarded the license to Majestic Star Casino, who agreed to pay $7.5 million for the first 30 years,[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Analysts:_Isle_of_Capri_Favored_to_Win-16) in addition to the Penguins paying $4 million per year.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pa._Gaming_Board_Awards_5_Slots_Licenses_in_Historic_Session-17)[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-ToBreak-18) The casino experienced financial difficulty, which could have led to taxpayers financing the entire project. However, on August 14, 2008, the Pennsylvania Gaming Control Board selected [Neil Bluhm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Bluhm "Neil Bluhm") to take ownership of the casinos, which pulled the casinos out of risk of bankruptcy.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Casino_Project_Back_on_Track-19) The casino, now known as the [Rivers Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rivers_Casino_(Pittsburgh) "Rivers Casino (Pittsburgh)"), eventually opened on August 9, 2009, in the North Side [Chateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chateau_(Pittsburgh) "Chateau (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood. [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg/250px-Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg) The arena in July 2009 The arena's funding plan was agreed upon by Lemieux, Pittsburgh mayor [Luke Ravenstahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luke_Ravenstahl "Luke Ravenstahl"), and Pennsylvania governor [Ed Rendell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Rendell "Ed Rendell") on March 13, 2007, after much negotiation.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) During negotiations, the Penguins explored moving the franchise to [Kansas City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri "Kansas City, Missouri") or [Las Vegas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas") (the latter of which [received an NHL expansion team in 2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights "Vegas Golden Knights")); after the deal was made the Penguins agreed to stay in Pittsburgh for at least 30 more years.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) Lemieux later stated that relocating the franchise was never a possibility, but instead it was a negotiation tactic to help the team get funding for the arena from both state and local officials.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Countdown_to_2010;_Arena_Construction_Begins-21) The arena was originally scheduled to open for the 2009–10 NHL season; however, this was pushed back to the 2010–11 NHL season.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_to_Open_New_Arena_in_2010%E2%80%9311_Season-22)[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Delay_Arena_Opening_Until_2010-23) The arena was expected to cost approximately $290 million, but rose to $321 million due to increased cost of steel and insurance.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Costrise-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-CostRiseTri-25) The Penguins agreed to pay $3.8 million per year toward construction, with an additional $400,000 per year toward capital improvements.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) After $31 million cost rise, the Penguins pledged an additional $15.5 million, while the State and Sports and Exhibition Authority split the difference.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Costrise-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-CostRiseTri-25) In September 2009, the State contributed an additional $5.08 million from the "Pennsylvania Gaming Economic Development and Tourism Fund" to cover a rising "interest on variable rate bonds".[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-erdley-26) ## Design and construction [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg) The arena in May 2009 [Populous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populous_(company) "Populous (company)"), designers of [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park") and [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field"), designed the building working with local architect Astorino to develop the construction documents, while the ICON Venue group and [Oxford Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_Development "Oxford Development") oversaw the building of the

pre-season game on September 22, 2010, with a 5–1 win over the rival [Detroit Red Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings"). Penguins [forward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_(ice_hockey) "Forward (ice hockey)") [Mike Comrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Comrie "Mike Comrie") scored the first goal in the new arena, 81 seconds into the game.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Open_Consol_Energy_Center_With_5%E2%80%931_Exhibition_Win-50) The team also added a third home pre-season game to the schedule. Team President David Morehouse said, "Our feeling is that more fans will want the chance to see and experience Consol Energy Center, so we thought it made sense to add the third preseason home game."[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pens_to_Open_New_Arena_With_Preseason_Game_vs._Detroit-51) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg) Inside PPG Paints Arena during a Penguins pre-season game in 2010. The Penguins officially opened the building on October 7, 2010, against their [cross-state rivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flyers%E2%80%93Penguins_rivalry "Flyers–Penguins rivalry") [Philadelphia Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers"), with the Penguins falling 3–2. The first goal was scored by the Flyers forward [Daniel Brière](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Bri%C3%A8re "Daniel Brière") at 2:51 in the 2nd period, a [power play](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_play_(sport) "Power play (sport)") goal. The first Penguin goal was scored by forward [Tyler Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyler_Kennedy "Tyler Kennedy") 44 seconds into the third period. The stars of the game were awarded to Kennedy, [Claude Giroux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Giroux "Claude Giroux") and Flyers rookie goaltender [Sergei Bobrovsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergei_Bobrovsky "Sergei Bobrovsky"), who made 29 of 31 saves in his NHL debut.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Flyers_spoil_Penguins'_Debut_in_New_Home_With_3%E2%80%932_Win-52) The Penguins earned their first win at the arena on October 15, 2010, against the [New York Islanders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Islanders "New York Islanders"), prevailing on an overtime power-play goal by defenseman [Alex Goligoski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Goligoski "Alex Goligoski"). It was also the first overtime game at the new arena. Goaltender [Brent Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brent_Johnson "Brent Johnson") earned the win for the Penguins, making 22 saves.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_3,_Islanders_2-53) The first playoff game in PPG Paints Arena was against the [Tampa Bay Lightning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Lightning "Tampa Bay Lightning") on April 13, 2011. The first playoff goal in the building was scored by [Alexei Kovalev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Kovalev "Alexei Kovalev"). The Penguins would go on to win the first playoff game by a score of 3–0. [Marc-André Fleury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc-Andr%C3%A9_Fleury "Marc-André Fleury") had a 32-save shutout. The Penguins would go on to lose in seven games.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-nhl-54) During the 2011 off-season, 300 seats were added, increasing the hockey [seating capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") from 18,087 to 18,387.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-add_seats-55) PPG Paints Arena hosted its first Stanley Cup Finals in [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2016 Stanley Cup Finals"), which saw the Penguins defeat the [San Jose Sharks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose_Sharks "San Jose Sharks") in six games to clinch its fourth Cup. Although the Penguins clinched the Cup at the [SAP Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAP_Center "SAP Center") (home of the Sharks), PPG Paints did host a watch party for what turned out to be the series-clinching game, charging $10 for admission with all proceeds going to the Pittsburgh Penguins Foundation. Concessions and the team store were open, and the arena's goal horn played after every Penguins goal just like at a regular home game.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-56) The arena hosted a similar watch party [the following year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2017 Stanley Cup Finals") for game six while the Penguins played the [Nashville Predators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville_Predators "Nashville Predators") at [Bridgestone Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bridgestone_Arena "Bridgestone Arena"), which like the year before turned out to be the series-clinching game for the Penguins' fifth Cup.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-57) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg/960px-Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg "Panorama view of the lower bowl of PPG Paints Arena before the first

2010, in the [City Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Game "City Game"), the first ever basketball game hosted in the venue. A neutral venue, Pitt was designated as the home team for the game,[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-jovenitti-63) which the Panthers won 80–66. The first points at the arena were made by Duquesne freshman guard [T. J. McConnell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._McConnell "T. J. McConnell"), with a basket at 27 seconds into the game.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-City_Game:_Pitt_Defeats_Duquesne,_80%E2%80%9366-64) The arena hosted the 2010 [SEC/Big East Invitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SEC/Big_East_Invitational "SEC/Big East Invitational"), featuring [Auburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auburn_Tigers_men%27s_basketball "Auburn Tigers men's basketball") playing [Rutgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutgers_Scarlet_Knights_men%27s_basketball "Rutgers Scarlet Knights men's basketball") and [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_men%27s_basketball "Pittsburgh Panthers men's basketball") taking on [Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Volunteers_basketball "Tennessee Volunteers basketball") in Pitt's second appearance at PPG Paints. The games were televised nationally on [ESPN2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN2 "ESPN2") and [ESPN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") respectively.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pitt-Tennessee_Set_for_Consol_Energy_Center-65) Duquesne hosted three home games in the 2010–11 season: on December 12 against [West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_West_Virginia_Mountaineers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team"), against [Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Dayton_Flyers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 Dayton Flyers men's basketball team") on January 30, 2011, and against [Xavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Xavier_Musketeers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 Xavier Musketeers men's basketball team") on February 13, 2011.[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Duquesne_University_Official_Athletic_Site_%E2%80%93_Men's_Basketball-66) During the [2012–2013 NHL lockout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%932013_NHL_lockout "2012–2013 NHL lockout"), Duquesne again hosted three home games – December 12 vs. [West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_West_Virginia_Mountaineers_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team"), January 19 vs. [VCU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_VCU_Rams_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 VCU Rams men's basketball team"), and February 9 vs. [Xavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Xavier_Musketeers_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 Xavier Musketeers men's basketball team"). For the 2013–14 basketball season, Duquesne hosted [Penn State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Penn_State_Nittany_Lions_basketball_team "2013–14 Penn State Nittany Lions basketball team") on December 11 and [Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Dayton_Flyers_men%27s_basketball_team "2013–14 Dayton Flyers men's basketball team") on February 22. Duquesne hosted round of 64 and round of 32 games of the [2012 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2012 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament") at the arena and hosted the round of 64 and round of 32 again in [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2015 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). Duquesne had hosted three prior times at Civic Arena: [1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "1997 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"), [2001 (women's)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_NCAA_Division_I_women%27s_basketball_tournament "2001 NCAA Division I women's basketball tournament") and [2002](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2002 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). In 2022 Duquesne hosted the Round of the [NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). During his tenure as [Commissioner of the NBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_the_NBA "Commissioner of the NBA"), [David Stern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Stern "David Stern") mentioned the arena as a possible home for an NBA franchise should one move to Pittsburgh.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-David_Stern:_Some_Owners_Not_Opposed_to_Contracting_New_Orleans_Hornets-67) For their 2017–18 season and part of the 2018–19 season, the arena served as the home of the [Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Robert_Morris_Colonials_men%27s_basketball_team "2017–18 Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team") for several games while the new UPMC Events Center was constructed on campus. ## Arena football [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg/250px-PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg) An interior panorama of PPG Paints Arena in Pittsburgh, PA Shortly after PPG Paints was built, the [Arena Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League") considered starting an expansion team in the arena,[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Eyes_Pittsburgh_for_Possible_Expansion-68) but the league folded in August 2009.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Appears_Close_to_Folding-69) However, after a [two-year hiatus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League#Canceled_2009_season/first_bankruptcy "Arena Football League"), the AFL returned and eyed an expansion team in Pittsburgh.[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-New_Arena_League_Reclaims_Old_Name,_Seeks_More_Teams-70) On August 19, 2010, news sources reported that PPG Paints Arena would be home to the [Pittsburgh Power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Power "Pittsburgh Power"), which began play in the spring of 2011. contexts.text: ##### The Café at the Frick Update Please note that The Café at the Frick will serving a limited menu, packaged and served to go, on October 3, 4, 5, and 7. We never stop learning # Learning at the Frick We believe that every visit is an opportunity to learn, to be inspired and to be delighted by art, history and nature, and we offer many different opportunities to learn in ways that mean the most to you. Take a guided tour of Clayton or explore the current exhibition on your own, join us for a workshop or a lunchtime lecture, or simply walk the grounds and feel refreshed. **We welcome you to visit and discover all that you can learn at the Frick.** _Looking to schedule a field trip? January and February offer more flexibility in available dates. Consider scheduling a program during this time to save $2 per student. [Learn more and schedule today!](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org//learn#education)_ ### For Educators Our hands-on learning programs for students K-12 are teacher friendly, address academic standards and use art, history, and nature to understand different times and contexts. Frick programs address cross curricular standards, integrating writing, art, science and even economics to broaden student perspectives. If you're interested in bringing your students to The Frick, our 2025-2026 School Programs Booklet is the best place to start the planning process. The booklet contains all of the information you need to plan an exciting, engaging field trip for your students, including program descriptions by grade level, lunch information, and tips for booking. By popular demand, we have also added an a la carte option that allows you to customize your own field trip experience! Download your free copy below. [School Program Booklet](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/Files/Admin/School%2DProgram%2DBooklet%2D2025%2D2026%2D%283%29.pdf?d=2025924134119) **If you plan to visit the Frick as a self-guided student group, please review our museum guidelines for self-guided groups ahead of your arrival.** [View Guidelines](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/Files/Admin/Museum%2DGuidelines%2Dfor%2DSelf%2DGuided%2DStudent%2DGroups%2Devergreen%2D2025.pdf?d=20254493241) #### [School Programs](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org//learn\#acc-tab2) The Frick Pittsburgh is committed to offering engaging, thoughtful student programs both online and on-site in our three museums. Our programs explore the interdisciplinary nature of the Frick—from fine art in The Frick Art Museum, to life in the gilded age in Clayton, to the history of transportation in our Car and Carriage Museum. [Learn More](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/school-programs) #### [Teacher Professional Development](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org//learn\#acc-tab3) At the Frick we not only welcome students, but teachers too! Throughout the year we offer teacher workshops that focus on a wide variety of art, history, and other educational topics through multidisciplinary, standards-based workshops. These programs offer Act 48 activity hours while providing teachers with fresh and practical classroom-ready suggestions. [View Programs](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/calendar?search=1&page=1&search_category=5) #### [Learning Resources](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org//learn\#acc-tab4) We offer a variety of multi-disciplinary resources designed to support educators at every grade level, regardless of whether they are teaching remotely or in the classroom. [View Resources](https://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/classroomresources) ## Family Programs The Frick Pittsburgh is a wonderful place to spend time with your family. We offer programs throughout the year that give families the opportunity to engage together in hands-on learning through museum visits, art making, and outdoor activities on our grounds. Our learning activities are for children of all

# Pittsburgh Pirates

Raise the Jolly Roger! Let's Go Bucs!

## Baseball in Pittsburgh

The best time to visit Pittsburgh is during baseball season, and an evening in Pittsburgh is best spent at one of the most popular ballparks in all of baseball, [PNC Park](https://www.mlb.com/pirates/ballpark). With downtown Pittsburgh serving as a scenic backdrop and a dramatic entry via the Roberto Clemente Bridge along the Allegheny River, you'll see why Pittsburghers and visitors love to [cheer for the Pittsburgh Pirates](http://www.mlb.com/pirates). ABC News, TripAdvisor, ESPN and more have named PNC Park as an ultimate site to catch a game with a spectacular view of the Downtown skyline.

And there is always great [food](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/what-to-eat-at-pnc-park/), events, [promotions and giveaways](http://www.mlb.com/pirates/tickets/promotions/2022) during baseball season. Don't miss your chance to win t-shirts, hats, backpacks and bobble heads. You can have a front-row seat as you see the skyline light up on Fireworks Night, bring your dog to the ballpark on Pup Night every Tuesday, or stay after the game for a free concert on specific evenings.

While you are in town for a game, stop by the [Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum](http://heinzhistorycenter.org/sportsMuseum.aspx%22%20%5Ct%20%22_blank%22%20%5Co%20%22external%20link) or the [Clemente Museum](http://www.clementemuseum.com/) and relive some of the great moments of Pittsburgh sports history.

So round up your family and friends and make your way down to PNC Park to catch a game. Let’s Go Bucs!

Share Your Story On Social #LOVEPGH

contexts.text: well as the two hosting the pre-game program _Steelers Kickoff_ during the regular season prior to the national airing of _[The NFL Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_NFL_Today "The NFL Today")_. Pompeani and former Steelers [lineman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lineman_(American_football) "Lineman (American football)") [Chris Hoke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Hoke "Chris Hoke") also host the _Xfinity Xtra Point_ following the game on days when [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS "CBS") does not have that week's NFL doubleheader. When CBS has a week's doubleheader, the show airs on WPKD-TV. Coach Mike Tomlin's weekly press conference is shown live on AT&T SportsNet Pittsburgh. Both Batch and Hoke replaced former Steelers lineman [Edmund Nelson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Nelson_(American_football) "Edmund Nelson (American football)"), who retired from broadcasting in 2015.[\[222\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-223) _[Thursday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thursday_Night_Football "Thursday Night Football")_ broadcasts are shown locally on [Fox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") affiliate [WPGH-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPGH-TV "WPGH-TV"), channel 53 (along with home games with NFC opponents and some flexed interconference games), while _[ESPN Monday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN_Monday_Night_Football "ESPN Monday Night Football")_ broadcasts are shown locally on [WTAE-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WTAE-TV "WTAE-TV"), channel 4. (WTAE-TV is owned by the [Hearst Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hearst_Corporation "Hearst Corporation"), which owns a 20% stake in ESPN.) By virtue of being members of the AFC, most of the Steelers' games air on CBS and KDKA. _[NBC Sunday Night Football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_Sunday_Night_Football "NBC Sunday Night Football")_ games are carried by [WPXI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPXI "WPXI"), channel 11, in the market. The Steelers hold a national contract with [Grupo Imagen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grupo_Imagen "Grupo Imagen") for radio rights to their games in Mexico; Imagen broadcasts the Steelers on their stations in 17 Mexican cities. ### Figures with broadcasting résumés Main article: [List of Pittsburgh Steelers figures in broadcasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pittsburgh_Steelers_figures_in_broadcasting "List of Pittsburgh Steelers figures in broadcasting") The Steelers franchise has a rich history of producing well-known sportscasters over the years. The most famous of these is probably [Myron Cope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myron_Cope "Myron Cope"), who served as a Steelers radio [color commentator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_commentator "Color commentator") for 35 seasons ( [1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "1970 Pittsburgh Steelers season")– [2004](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2004 Pittsburgh Steelers season")).[\[223\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-n230-224) Several former Steelers players have gone on to careers in media after completing their playing careers. ### Newspaper The _Steelers Digest_ is the only official newspaper for the Pittsburgh Steelers.[\[224\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-i972-225) It has been published for 22 years and is currently published by Dolphin/Curtis Publishing in Miami, Florida, which also handles several other publications. The newspaper is very widely acknowledged by Steelers fans. Issues are mailed out to paying subscribers weekly through the season after every regular-season game and continue through playoffs as long as the Steelers do. After a Super Bowl victory, a bonus issue is published, which is followed by a draft preview, draft recap, and training camp edition every other month, then leading into the pre-season. There are typically 24 issues of the paper within a publishing year. The newspaper is listed on the official Steelers.com page. ### Usage in popular culture - The January 11, 1975, episode of the _[Mary Tyler Moore Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Tyler_Moore_Show "Mary Tyler Moore Show")_ featured [Super Bowl IX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Bowl_IX "Super Bowl IX") (featuring the Steelers) as a plot device.[\[225\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-p506-226) - _[Black Sunday](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Sunday_(1977_film) "Black Sunday (1977 film)")_ in 1977[\[226\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-r500-227) - _[Heaven Can Wait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heaven_Can_Wait_(1978_film) "Heaven Can Wait (1978 film)")_ in 1978[\[227\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-h078-228) - _[Smokey and the Bandit II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smokey_and_the_Bandit_II "Smokey and the Bandit II")_ in

- MOBILE TICKET BARCODE #### What is a Mobile Ticket Barcode? Each ticket has a mobile ticket barcode that must be scanned for entry into PNC Park via your mobile device. Within the Wallet, you can tap on an individual ticket to view its barcode. For entry to PNC Park, present your mobile device with the mobile barcode open and available to scan. #### How do I access the ticket to scan for entry? Tap on an individual ticket from the Tickets tab’s Wallet to pull up the mobile ticket barcode. The Section/Row/Seat and barcode will be displayed along with access to the terms and conditions governing your ticket. #### Why is my ticket barcode not showing in the MLB Ballpark app? There are several reasons why your barcode may not be available including that the ticket has been forwarded, the ticket had been forwarded to you and has since been canceled or recalled, or you are a group or suite buyer and the ticket status has changed. For mailed tickets, the ticket barcode will not appear until those tickets have been printed and mailed to you. For further assistance, contact Pirates Fans Services at [ticketservices@pirates.com](mailto:ticketservices@pirates.com) or 1-800-BUY-BUCS. #### I just forwarded a ticket via the MLB Ballpark app. Why do I still see it? Your ticket, without the barcode, will remain in your Tickets tab’s Wallet until your forward is accepted by the recipient. If you wish to cancel the forward, you can do that directly from the ticket. #### During what window of time can I forward tickets to friends? You can forward tickets via the MLB Ballpark app from the moment you purchase them until two hours after the first pitch of that day's game as long as that ticket has not already been scanned in for entry at PNC Park. #### What should I do if I need to enter PNC Park for the start of the game and the rest of my group is not here yet? You can easily forward tickets to friends via the MLB Ballpark app up to two hours after the start of that day's game as long as the tickets have not already been scanned in for entry at PNC Park. #### Can I use Apple Wallet for my Pirates tickets? Yes. From the bottom of the ticket inside the MLB Ballpark app you can tap the "Add to Wallet" button to add your ticket to Apple Wallet. #### Can I use Google Pay for my Pirates tickets? No. Support for adding tickets to Google Pay is not yet available from the MLB Ballpark app. #### Why won't my ticket barcode scan? If your screen brightness is too low, the barcode may have difficulty being scanned. The MLB Ballpark app will automatically attempt to increase the brightness of your display or you can do so manually by following the instructions for your device. Please note, cracked screens may impact your barcode's ability to scan. The barcode displayed is accompanied by a number. If there are difficulties reading a valid barcode on a

[Chuck Noll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll") had the longest term as head coach with the Steelers; he is one of only four coaches to coach a single NFL team for 23 years.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-History-7) Hired prior to the [2007 season](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2007 Pittsburgh Steelers season"), the Steelers current coach is [Mike Tomlin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Tomlin "Mike Tomlin").[\[219\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-220) ### Current staff **Pittsburgh Steelers staff** ### Offensive coordinator history Source:[\[220\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-AllTimeSteelersCoaches-221) ### Defensive coordinator history Source:[\[220\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers#cite_note-AllTimeSteelersCoaches-221) ## Media [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png/250px-Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Steelers_radio_affiliates.png) Map of radio affiliates. Both stations are owned by [iHeartMedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IHeartMedia "IHeartMedia"). question: What was the Steelers' record entering their 2025 bye week?
answer: The Steelers entered their 2025 bye week with a 3-1 record.

contexts.text: # First half of Steelers' season loaded with memorable plays Nov 01, 2024 at 12:00 PM [Dale Lolley](https://www.steelers.com/author/dale-lolley) Contributing Writer/Editor [Opens Twitter profile page in new window - Opens new window](https://twitter.com/dlolley_pgh) - Copied! The Steelers head into their bye week at 6-2 and in first place in the AFC North. How they have gotten to this point has been an interesting dichotomy of today's NFL. During a three-game winning streak to open the season, the defense was dominant, allowing just 26 total points. During a two-game losing streak, the defense, which had been the backbone of the winning streak to open the season, showed some leakage, giving up 27 and 20 points, too many for a team playing with its backup quarterback, as the Steelers were to open the season. But during a three-game winning streak heading into the bye week, the offense, defense and special teams have all played in unison. That has led to some lopsided scores and the 6-2 record that has Steelers sitting atop the division, a position the team will hold when it next plays Nov. 10 at Washington regardless of what happens this weekend. And the Steelers have gotten there despite a number of injuries that could have sent the team into a spiral. To wit, the offensive line has had four different players make their first career NFL start and has utilized five different starting combinations because of a number of injuries up front. Add to that games missed by, among others, outside linebackers Alex Highsmith and Nick Herbig and running backs Jaylen Warren and Cordarrelle Patterson, let alone quarterback Russell Wilson missing the first six games of the season with a calf injury, and the it would be more understandable that the Steelers would be 2-6 instead of 6-2. With Wilson injured, Justin Fields started the Steelers' first six games and helped the team to a 4-2 start, showing that the team's deft handling of the makeover of its quarterback room from 2023 was well worth the gamble. Fields, just 10-28 as a starter in Chicago, accounted for 10 touchdowns and two turnovers in his six starts, while Wilson has thrown for three scores and rushed for another in his two starts. The acquisition of those two quarterbacks – along with third-stringer Kyle Allen – were just three of the offseason moves made by GM Omar Khan. And all of his moves have largely paid dividends in the first half of the season. Cornerback Donte Jackson, linebacker Patrick Queen and safety DeShon Elliott all have been major additions to the defense. So, too, has been third-round draft pick Payton Wilson at linebacker. On the offensive side of things, first-round pick Troy Fautanu was unfortunately injured after making his first career start, but second-round selection Zach Frazier has arguably been the NFL's best rookie offensive lineman before missing the past two games with an ankle injury. He is expected to return after the bye week. Meanwhile, fourth-round selection Mason McCormick has moved into the starting lineup at right guard in place of an injured James

tackle Cam Heyward got his hands up, forcing Rodgers to double-clutch on the pass. That gave Beanie Bishop the opportunity to step underneath Garrett Wilson and intercept the pass at the Pittsburgh 46. Four plays later, Russell Wilson tossed an 11-yard TD to George Pickens, cutting New York's lead to 15-13 and starting a run of 31 consecutive points for the Steelers. Bishop also would pick off Rodgers in the third quarter to set up another touchdown. _•_ _Dale Lolley is co-host of "SNR Drive" on Steelers Nation Radio. Subscribe to the podcast here:_ [Apple Podcast](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/snr-drive-with-matt-dale-pittsburgh-steelers/id1445185242) \| [iHeart Podcast](https://www.iheart.com/podcast/256-snr-drive-with-matt-dale-p-31132091?cmp=ios_share&sc=ios_social_share&pr=false&autoplay=true) _Week 7, 2:42 3rd quarter, against New York Jets_ With the Steelers leading 23-15, the Jets lined up for a 35-yard field goal attempt. But Greg Zuerlein's attempt was blocked by defensive lineman Dean Lowry, turning the Jets away without points. It marked the third consecutive game in which the Steelers blocked a kick, tying a team record for most blocks in consecutive games and blocks in a single season. _Week 8, 4:58 3rd quarter, against New York Giants_ The Steelers were locked in a 9-9 tie with the visiting Giants when an Alex Highsmith sack helped force New York to punt. Austin fielded the punt at his own 27 on the right hash, cut all the way back across the field, picking up a block on the edge from Rodney Williams and sprinted up the sideline for a 73-yard punt return touchdown. It was the Steelers' first punt return for a score since 2019. On the Steelers' next possession, Austin would catch a 29-yard touchdown pass from Wilson, helping the Steelers to their sixth win. _Week 8, 3:03 4th quarter, against New York Giants_ With the Steelers leading 26-18, Wilson fumbled on a scramble, with the Giants recovering at the Pittsburgh 37. But with the Giants at the 19, Watt whipped his block at the snap, hit quarterback Daniel Jones and forced him to fumble, recovering the loose ball himself. The Steelers would run the clock down to two minutes while moving out to midfield before punting. And Bishop would record his third interception in two weeks in the closing seconds to seal the win for the Steelers. ## Related Content [![](https://static.clubs.nfl.com/image/upload/t_editorial_landscape_mobile/t_lazy/f_auto/steelers/rj2x6jlmd2sgprf4yxxo.jpg)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **Winning while building**\\ \\ The Steelers head into their bye week with a 3-1 record](https://www.steelers.com/news/winning-while-building "Winning while building") [![](https://static.clubs.nfl.com/image/upload/t_editorial_landscape_mobile/t_lazy/f_png/steelers/i7btzicosviyf83wurca.png)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **Five Fast Facts: Brandin Echols**\\ \\ Learn more about Brandin Echols in this edition of Five Fast Facts](https://www.steelers.com/news/five-fast-facts-brandin-echols "Five Fast Facts: Brandin Echols") [![](https://static.clubs.nfl.com/image/upload/t_editorial_landscape_mobile/t_lazy/f_png/steelers/hxpq5fwt6jwfdmbzs7m5.png)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **Five Fast Facts: Darius Slay**\\ \\ Learn more about Darius Slay in this edition of Five Fast Facts](https://www.steelers.com/news/five-fast-facts-darius-slay "Five Fast Facts: Darius Slay") [![](https://static.clubs.nfl.com/image/upload/t_editorial_landscape_mobile/t_lazy/f_png/steelers/gfbre5360twmbebktymu.png)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **Five Fast Facts: Kaleb Johnson**\\ \\ Learn more about Kaleb Johnson in this edition of Five Fast Facts](https://www.steelers.com/news/five-fast-facts-kaleb-johnson "Five Fast Facts: Kaleb Johnson") [![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **The voice of experience**\\ \\ Seumalo's play, presence counted upon to steady youngsters up front](https://www.steelers.com/news/the-voice-of-experience "The voice of experience") [![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)\\ \\ news\\ \\ \\ **Five Fast Facts: Malik Harrison**\\

# Winning while building Oct 04, 2025 at 09:00 AM [Jim Wexell](https://www.steelers.com/author/jim-wexell) Correspondent - Copied! Winning while building. That's a view of the Steelers season after four games. It's both apt and optimistic for a 3-1 team that saw a 50 percent turnover of the players (who comprised the top 13 amount of snaps on both sides of the ball) in the 2024 and 2025 openers. Fifty percent turnover is a massive change. And the turnover from 2024 playoff lineup to 2025 opener was 38 percent, still a sizable turnover. For a coach whose goal of the preseason was to get his players to "the starting line" in good health, the building -- the true team building -- didn't begin until the regular season did. And the Steelers have obviously improved from Week One to Week Four, when the sizable import of new players began to settle in. The Steelers entered their bye week at 3-1 with road wins against two AFC opponents. The fact they rank 29th in offense and 28th in defense offers promise that so much improvement is yet to occur. How did they do it? Well, their "turnover culture" is alive and well. The Steelers are second in the NFL with a +7 margin in turnovers, much of that due to a third-place standing in total sacks with 14. They are also seventh in red zone TD percentage, so they not only get extra chances with turnovers, they take advantage with touchdowns. Individually, only Aaron Rodgers has a top-10 spot in key rankings. The Steelers' new QB is fourth with 8 TD passes and ninth with a 102.6 passer rating. But statistics don't tell the story of "winning while building" at 3-1. The highlights have kept Steelers Nation on the edge of its collective seat throughout the first quarter of the season. Here's a game-by-game look at the best of the first four games: **Steelers 34, Jets 32** \- First TD of the season a play-action, roll right pass from Rodgers to a wide open Ben Skowronek. \- Chris Boswell kicked field goals of 56 and a team-record 60 yards, the latter turning out to be the game-winner with 1:03 remaining. \- On a late-game fourth-and-3 for the Jets, Steelers cornerback Jalen Ramsey drilled Jets wide receiver Garrett Wilson to jar the ball loose and seal the Steelers' win. # [PHOTOS: Karl's top pics - Steelers at Jets](https://www.steelers.com/photos/photos-karl-s-top-pics-steelers-at-jets-x8049) Take a look at Karl's best photos from the Week 1 matchup against the New York Jets 1 / 81 Pittsburgh Steelers running back Kaleb Johnson (20) prior to a regular season game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New York Jets, Sunday, Sept. 7, 2025 in East Rutherford, NJ. The Steelers defeated the Jets 34-32. (Karl Roser / Pittsburgh Steelers) Karl Roser/Pittsburgh Steelers 2 / 81 Pittsburgh Steelers linebacker Alex Highsmith (56) prior to a regular season game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New York Jets, Sunday, Sept. 7, 2025 in East Rutherford, NJ. The Steelers defeated the Jets 34-32. (Karl Roser / Pittsburgh Steelers) Karl Roser/Pittsburgh Steelers

contexts.text: 2010, in the [City Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Game "City Game"), the first ever basketball game hosted in the venue. A neutral venue, Pitt was designated as the home team for the game,[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-jovenitti-63) which the Panthers won 80–66. The first points at the arena were made by Duquesne freshman guard [T. J. McConnell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._J._McConnell "T. J. McConnell"), with a basket at 27 seconds into the game.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-City_Game:_Pitt_Defeats_Duquesne,_80%E2%80%9366-64) The arena hosted the 2010 [SEC/Big East Invitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SEC/Big_East_Invitational "SEC/Big East Invitational"), featuring [Auburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auburn_Tigers_men%27s_basketball "Auburn Tigers men's basketball") playing [Rutgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutgers_Scarlet_Knights_men%27s_basketball "Rutgers Scarlet Knights men's basketball") and [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_men%27s_basketball "Pittsburgh Panthers men's basketball") taking on [Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Volunteers_basketball "Tennessee Volunteers basketball") in Pitt's second appearance at PPG Paints. The games were televised nationally on [ESPN2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN2 "ESPN2") and [ESPN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") respectively.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pitt-Tennessee_Set_for_Consol_Energy_Center-65) Duquesne hosted three home games in the 2010–11 season: on December 12 against [West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_West_Virginia_Mountaineers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team"), against [Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Dayton_Flyers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 Dayton Flyers men's basketball team") on January 30, 2011, and against [Xavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Xavier_Musketeers_men%27s_basketball_team "2010–11 Xavier Musketeers men's basketball team") on February 13, 2011.[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Duquesne_University_Official_Athletic_Site_%E2%80%93_Men's_Basketball-66) During the [2012–2013 NHL lockout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%932013_NHL_lockout "2012–2013 NHL lockout"), Duquesne again hosted three home games – December 12 vs. [West Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_West_Virginia_Mountaineers_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team"), January 19 vs. [VCU](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_VCU_Rams_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 VCU Rams men's basketball team"), and February 9 vs. [Xavier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_Xavier_Musketeers_men%27s_basketball_team "2012–13 Xavier Musketeers men's basketball team"). For the 2013–14 basketball season, Duquesne hosted [Penn State](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Penn_State_Nittany_Lions_basketball_team "2013–14 Penn State Nittany Lions basketball team") on December 11 and [Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Dayton_Flyers_men%27s_basketball_team "2013–14 Dayton Flyers men's basketball team") on February 22. Duquesne hosted round of 64 and round of 32 games of the [2012 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2012 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament") at the arena and hosted the round of 64 and round of 32 again in [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2015 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). Duquesne had hosted three prior times at Civic Arena: [1997](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "1997 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"), [2001 (women's)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_NCAA_Division_I_women%27s_basketball_tournament "2001 NCAA Division I women's basketball tournament") and [2002](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "2002 NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). In 2022 Duquesne hosted the Round of the [NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_men%27s_basketball_tournament "NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"). During his tenure as [Commissioner of the NBA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_the_NBA "Commissioner of the NBA"), [David Stern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Stern "David Stern") mentioned the arena as a possible home for an NBA franchise should one move to Pittsburgh.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-David_Stern:_Some_Owners_Not_Opposed_to_Contracting_New_Orleans_Hornets-67) For their 2017–18 season and part of the 2018–19 season, the arena served as the home of the [Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Robert_Morris_Colonials_men%27s_basketball_team "2017–18 Robert Morris Colonials men's basketball team") for several games while the new UPMC Events Center was constructed on campus. ## Arena football [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg/250px-PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg) An interior panorama of PPG Paints Arena in Pittsburgh, PA Shortly after PPG Paints was built, the [Arena Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League") considered starting an expansion team in the arena,[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Eyes_Pittsburgh_for_Possible_Expansion-68) but the league folded in August 2009.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Appears_Close_to_Folding-69) However, after a [two-year hiatus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League#Canceled_2009_season/first_bankruptcy "Arena Football League"), the AFL returned and eyed an expansion team in Pittsburgh.[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-New_Arena_League_Reclaims_Old_Name,_Seeks_More_Teams-70) On August 19, 2010, news sources reported that PPG Paints Arena would be home to the [Pittsburgh Power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Power "Pittsburgh Power"), which began play in the spring of 2011. The team's ownership

question: In what year did Meadowcroft Historic Village open to the public?
answer: Meadowcroft Historic Village opened to the public in 1969.

# Meadowcroft Rockshelter

Dig into archaeological evidence that reveals the earliest signs of human habitation dating back 19,000 years.

If not for the curiosity of a Washington County, Pa., farmer six decades ago, Meadowcroft Rockshelter – the oldest site of human habitation in North America – might have never been discovered. In 1955, Albert Miller stumbled upon a groundhog hole on his family’s farm in Avella and uncovered what looked to be a prehistoric tool.

Miller chose to cover up the hole and carefully search for a professional archeologist who could properly assess the historical significance of the site. Almost two decades later in 1973, Miller finally connected with University of Pittsburgh anthropology professor Dr. James Adovasio who visited the farm and looked at the object found near the groundhog hole.

Astonished by the artifact, which was a prehistoric flint knife, Dr. Adovasio assembled a team of archaeology, anthropology and geology students to study the area as part of a curriculum. The field school’s excavation of the site over the next six years yielded nearly two million artifacts and ecofacts, including ancient stone tools, pottery fragments, and evidence of ice-age fire pits.

Further testing of the newly found artifacts concluded that the rock ledge overhang – naturally formed by the waters of Cross Creek – served as a campsite for prehistoric hunters and gatherers 19,000 years ago. Meadowcroft Rockshelter provided shelter for visitors with nearby fresh water springs and sources of plants and animals for food.

In 2005, the U.S. Secretary of the Interior designated Meadowcroft Rockshelter a National Historic Landmark.

Discover this important archeological treasure for yourself and visit Meadowcroft Rockshelter and Historic Village. Tours of the Rockshelter are available during regular operating hours and begin in the Meadowcroft visitor center.

**During Meadowcroft’s open season, daily tours of the Rockshelter begin at the Visitors Center. Tour times vary and last approximately one hour.**

For information about scheduling and reservations, please contact Meadowcroft at 724-587-3412 or meadowcroftinfo@heinzhistorycenter.org.

## Explore the Rockshelter

Meadowcroft Rockshelter and Historic Village

This GigaPan is a series of interactive images that allows anyone to explore the Meadowcroft Rockshelter archaeological site from any computer. This project was made possible through the generous support of the Claude Worthington Benedum Foundation, and through partnership with Carnegie Mellon University’s CREATE Lab and Learning Media Design Center.

question: From which county was the Pine Bank Covered Bridge relocated to Meadowcroft?
answer: The Pine Bank Covered Bridge was relocated to Meadowcroft from Greene County.

contexts.text:
# Meadowcroft Historic Village

Heavily altered by a coal mining operation, the landscape of Albert and Delvin Miller’s Avella farm drastically changed during the 1940s and 50s. The Millers were determined to reclaim the land and restore it to a new place where youth groups could camp and learn about history and the natural environment.

The Miller family began collecting examples of 19th century rural architecture, such as the Pine Bank Covered Bridge from neighboring Greene County, a barn slated for demolition on state game lands, and a log house constructed by their great-great-grandfather in 1800.

By 1969, the Meadowcroft Historic Village and its collection of 19th century artifacts and structures was ready to open to the public.

Today, visitors are amazed as they tour through the recreated Upper Ohio Valley Village, interact with various re-enactors, and enjoy living history demonstrations designed to show how Western Pennsylvanians once lived.

Get educated with a lesson in a one-room schoolhouse, experience a reassembled 1870s log church, watch a blacksmith forge red-hot iron, and step back in time at Meadowcroft’s Historic Village.

[![A panoramic shot of the Mister Rogers statue in the North Shore area.](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Top Free Things to Do in Pittsburgh \\ \\ Learn More](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/free-things-to-do/)[![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Shopping \\ \\ Learn More](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/things-to-do/shopping/)[![](data:image/svg+xml;charset=utf-8,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%27http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg%27%20width%3D%271%27%20height%3D%271%27%20style%3D%27background%3Atransparent%27%2F%3E)\\ \\ \\ Plan Your Trip \\ \\ Learn More](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/plan-your-trip/) # Pittsburgh Skyline Pittsburgh's skyline is full of architectural and cultural history. Visit the Fort Pitt Block House, Frick Building and many more during your visit. ## Downtown ### Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail Complex Stunningly beautiful. Singularly graceful. A symphony of arches. Considered by many to be the leading architect of the 19th century, Henry Hobson Richardson's 19th century neo-medieval design combines stunning brickwork and crisp granite detail. An outdoor fountain in the courtyard park highlights the magnificent riverfront structure, while the Bridge of Sighs (mirroring the Venice original) --at one time used to transport prisoners--connects the Courthouse to the former jail. What Richardson considered his best work remains among elite architectural company in Pittsburgh's Golden Triangle. ### BNY Mellon Born out of a merger between The Bank of New York and Mellon Financial Corporation, The Bank of New York Mellon has a substantial Pittsburgh presence. It's the oldest banking corporation in the nation - tracing its roots back to Alexander Hamilton. BNY Mellon Center is 55 stories and was completed in 1983. It is the second-tallest building in the city, boasts an eight-sided design and a rooftop heliport. On a clear day it is possible to spot the building from as far as 50 miles away. ### Fort Pitt Block House The Block House is the oldest structure in the City of Pittsburgh and the last vestige of the British Empire, built here in 1764 by the English Army. Much of its original fabric is still intact and it is open and free to the public year-round as an historic landmark. The Block House is the focal point in Point State Park where the three rivers of Pittsburgh, the Allegheny, the Ohio and the Monongahela, meet. ### Frick Building The Frick Building (1901-02), the first of industrialist Henry Clay Frick's architectural ventures on Grant Street, Downtown. In 1903, Leslie's Weekly judged it "the finest office building in the world," and no wonder: Daniel Burnham gave the coke and steel king a vertical version of the White City, a neo-classical tower with a dazzling white, T-shaped marble lobby, clean and crisp as a new dollar bill; bronze lions flanking the entrance; and John La Farge's stained glass window, "Fortune and Her Wheel," above a marble bust of Frick installed after his death in 1919. ### Fifth Avenue Place Home to Highmark, Pennsylvania's largest health insurer, Fifth Avenue Place was completed in 1988 and has 31 floors. The structure is made of a unique granite frame for roughly 450 feet and then collapses inward in a pyramid shape for another 124-foot-tall roof structure. Protruding from the top of the skyscraper is a 178-foot-tall mast. Despite its rounded appearance, the 13-story structure is actually 12-sided and measures four feet in diameter. ### Gulf Tower Rising 44 stories above the Downtown skyline,

Due to conflicts with construction, Aguilera canceled her show.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] ## In media _[Justified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justified_(TV_series) "Justified (TV series)")_, an [FX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FX_(TV_channel) "FX (TV channel)") television drama that debuted in March 2010, used the center's final construction phase as a filming location to depict the "new Federal Courthouse" on the show.[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-'Justified'_Another_Worthy_FX_Offering-78) _[Grudge Match](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grudge_Match_(film) "Grudge Match (film)")_ a 2013 film shot its climactic fight scene at the PPG Paints Arena.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] ## References 01. **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_ref-inflation-US_1-0 "Jump up")**1634–1699: [McCusker, J.
